BOOTH AT LA JEUNESSE COSMETICS, INC.
// JAVASCRIPT APPENDED BY WAYBACK MACHINE, COPYRIGHT INTE
INT. HALLWAY IN FRONT OF JUDD'S APT- AFTERNOON
I RUNNE TO DEATH AND DEATH MEETS ME AS FAST,
AND ALL MY PLEASURES ARE LIKE YESTERDAY. -
// ALL OTHER CONTENT MAY ALSO BE PROTECTED BY COPYRIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA HOLDS ON the stained glass window. Beneath the painted figures is a scroll, and on the scroll, a part of stained glass window, is an inscription:

dialogues.speaker: AND ALL MY PLEASURES ARE LIKE YESTERDAY. -
dialogues.text: John Donne, Holy Sonnets VI. As the CAMERA CONTINUES TO HOLD, the jumbled sound of classroom recitations can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s. from classroom above camera level) Amo, arias, amat, amamus, amatis, amant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s. from classroom below camera level) One times nine is nine. Two times nine is eighteen. Three times nine is twenty-seven. Four times nine is thirty-six

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s. from classroom above camera level, singing) Do, no, mi, Pa, sol, la, ti, do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These classroom sounds, although they can be heard clearl should not disturb the serenity of the stairway or of the painted figures on which the CAMERA IS LEVELED. Suddenly, from overhead, a gong rings with a harsh, jarri noise. Doors are heard opening, feet scuffling over the f and the light, high sound of girls' voices chattering. A moment later a cascade of uniformed schoolgirls of all ag pours down the stairs past the camera. Against this tide single girl makes her way. The CAMERA PANS WITH her up the remainder of the short fl of stairs and across the hallway to a door marked, PRINCI The girl knocks and from inside an overВ— cultured woman' voice is heard in response,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - Mary Gibson at the door. She hesitates befor opening it. She is young and her youth gives her prettine but something in the quiet serenity of her face and the c candor of the eyes show the innate niceness of the girl; quality of character which will give her real beauty as s grows older. At the moment she is somewhat perplexed by h unexpected summons by the Head Mistress. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Mary as she opens the door and looks expectantly toward the desk. No one is there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we are, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. LONG SHOT as Mary walks into the room. It is a large room and every effort has been made to invest it with authority. A large Sheraton desk with side trays stands a one end. On the wall behind this desk hangs a gloomy, dou visaged portrait of the founder of the school. The wall opposite the door is pierced by a large window. There are several bookcases with dull-looking volumes; books of reference and encyclopedia. On top of one of these cases the white, plaster head of Athena. The walls are covered enormous framed, sepia-tinted prints of the Acropolis, th Colosseum, Trajan's Column and other celebrated ruins. Mrs. Lowood, the Principal, a solidly built lady with iro gray hair and her assistant, Miss Gilcrist, a slim, frail lady of indeterminate age, are at a small table at the en the room. They are cutting out paper hearts. As Mary come to them, Mrs. Lowood finishes cutting out a paper heart a lays down the scissors with an air of satisfaction. With close behind her, she starts toward the desk. Miss Gilcri follows. The CAMERA PANS WITH them as they cross the room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a most painful matter to discuss with you, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks concerned. Mrs. Lowood has reached her desk, while Mary stands wonde what might come next. Mrs. Lowood deliberately seats hers and puts her fingertips together firmly. Over this Gothic arch she speaks to Mary. Miss Gilcrist takes her accustom place beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your sister - - have you heard from her lately?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mrs. Lowood, she doesn't write often.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you any other relatives, Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Jacqueline brought me up. (smiling) Somehow I never felt I needed other relatives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lowood nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes it all the more difficult В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little alarmed) Difficult? Has anything happened to Jacqueline?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know, Mary. We've been unable to get in touch with your sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved) Sometimes she can be quite careless. Why don't you try Mrs. Redi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have written repeatedly to Mrs. Redi. She vouchsafes no information whatsoever. (pauses) It is six months since your tuition has been paid, Mary. Naturally, it is impossible for you to stay on here as a paying pupil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a small voice) Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Gilcrist and I have talked it over. You can remain here and work with the younger children as a sort of assistant teacher. These Valentine cut-outs for instance В—- (holds one up) -- it's something you could do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to get up as if everything were decided.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Mrs. Lowood, I can't just stay here not knowing what's happened to my sister. Maybe if I went to New York -- if I saw Mrs. Redi myself --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt if you'll get anything out of that woman. But if (shrugging) you'd like to try, I'll advance you the money to make the trip to New York. Of course, my dear, if you don't find your sister, you can always come back here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (catching the note of high minded dismissal) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and starts for the door. Miss Gilcrist goes wit her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary comes out of Mrs. Lowood's office, closely followed  by Miss Gilcrist, who closes the door softly behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, don't come back. No matter if you never find your sister -В— no matter what happens to you -- don't come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks at her in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a kindly, more explanatory tone) My parents died when I was a pupil. I left, as you are leaving, but I didn't have courage -- one must have courage to really live in the world -- I came back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two stand looking at each other for a moment, while M realizes what her future may be -- what Miss Gilcrist is then suddenly the ringing notes of Mrs. Lowood's voice co from the other side of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gilcrist!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Gilcrist starts, turns automatically to open the doo then looks back at Mary. With a fond glance, she pats her before opening the door and going on into Mrs. Lowood's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stained glass window. The rain pours against the glas and the boughs of the tree beat back and forth. Mary come down the stairs dressed in plain travelling clothes. She carries her bag in one hand. She hears the familiar sound daily classroom recitations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Je cherche Tu cherches Ell cherahe Nous cherohons Vous cherchez Elba cherohent

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The French lesson dies away and we hear Mrs. Lowood's voi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes --- ! John Quincy Adams did not follow John Adams as President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary smiles. In the distance some young girl's fingers fa awkwardly over the melancholy chords of Traumerei. Mary reaches the bottom of the stairway and passes the big, fu oak grandfather's clock which stands with majestic infini of time, reminding all tardy students that it is later th they know. As she passes it, it rings the hour. She looks its friendly, familiar face, and gives it a little pat of farewell. O.S. we hear a sweeping girl's voice reciting t final verse of "The Chambered Nautilus."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Build thee more stately mansions, 0 my soul, As the swift seasons roll; Leave thy low-vaulted past! Let each new temple, nobler than the last Shut thee from heaven with a dome more vast, Till thou at length art free, Leaving thins outgrown shell by life's unresting sea;;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With this burst of poetic encouragement, Mary crosses the hallway, opens the door and passes out of Highcliffe Acad closing the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSEUP of a column of white powder falling from an oscillating sifter. The powder falls into a large barrel, the column of powder and its attendant dust hide from vie the three figures behind it. We hear the throaty voice of Mrs. Redi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a click as the apparatus is turned off. The powd stops falling. Three people are disclosed. Mary, still in travelling suit; Mrs. Redi, a neat, businesslike woman, w firm features and a steady eye. Her hair is extremely well coifed. Not a strand is out of place. Her clothes are covered by a long, white surgeon' coat of immaculate linen. The third person is a workman, dressed in a white smock and wearing a long, snouted, inhalator mask, which he removes, revealing a benign and smiling face. Mrs. Redi rubs a bit of the powder on the palm of her han She examines it critically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Joseph) It seems all right, Joseph.  (turning to Mary with a strained smile) You see, we do keep up the quality of La Jeunesse products in spite of Jacqueline's absence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She and Mary start down the line of machines toward a fun and tube arrangement set up for filling bottles. The CAME DOLLYS WITH them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they go, evidently resuming a previous discussion) But you must know someone who has seen or heard of my sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) I'm afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach the bottle-filling apparatus. Mrs. Redi lifts of the bottles and holds it up to the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your sister had many friends --but they were not my friends. I was only the manager of her plant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sets down the bottle and they move on. The CAMERA GOE WITH them. Mary, embarrassed, looks at her. They have rea a machine which pours luke-warm cleansing cream into grea jars. As one of the jars slides out from the machine, Mrs Redi picks it up, rubs a bit of cream from the top of the onto the back of her hand, and judges the rapidity with w the cream dissolves at body temperature. Evidently it mee with her approval, for she passes on and goes toward her office. Mary goes with her. At the door they stop a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Redi, there's one thing В—-with Jacqueline gone, how do you carry on the business? What do you do with the receipts? How do you sign checks--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Mary, I'm amazed. Didn't Jacqueline tell you? She sold the business to me at least eight months ago. It's my business now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still smiling) Yes В—В— and I must say I've done very well with it -- perhaps even better than Jacqueline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move on toward Mrs. Redi's office. INT. SALON - LA JEUNESSE -DAY. 8Mary and Mrs. Redi come into the salon. Beauty operators at work on patrons in several of the booths. The modernis glass walls, some patterned with stripes, the mirrors, an the gleaming gadgets make of this ordinary room a rather fantastic and distorted place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing you can think of -- old letters, anything, that might give me some hint as to where I might find Jacqueline?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me your address, and if I find anything, I'll get in touch with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm stopping at the Chatsworth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an air of dismissal) Thank you, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Redi puts her hand on the knob of the door marked "OFFICE." Mary starts off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary passes through the salon. As she passes one booth, a young woman in the white smock of an operator comes out. is Frances, a tense, nervous young woman, with bleached b hair and excited, nervous eyes..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with great friendliness) Why, Mary --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Frances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Miss Jacqueline?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. That's why I came to see Mrs. Redi. I'm trying to find her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean Miss Jacqueline's gone, and you don't know where she is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary nods. Frances beckons to Mary, and they pass through side door into a corridor that connects the plant with th street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a narrow, gloomy passage. The two girls come into i from the side door. Frances fishes a package of cigarette from her pocket, takes one, lights it as she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get this. Miss Jacqueline was always so fond of you -- she was always talking about you -В— had your picture in her office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. For the first time I'm beginning to be frightened. I almost feel as if I'd never known my sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing's happened to her. It's just that I can't understand her not getting in touch with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't understand it at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't worry. I saw Miss Jacqueline only a week ago. I saw her at a little restaurant the boy friend took me to -- an Italian place down in the Village В—-        "The Dante."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Dante?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's on Peary Street. Just ask the people who run it. They'll remember her. (with reminiscent pride) People who see Miss Jacqueline never forget her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll try there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to return to the salon, but Frances indicates her there is a short cut to the street by means of the lo hallway. The two girls smile at each other. Frances turns back into the salon and Mary starts down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: INC.- DAY
dialogues.text: Mary comes out of the side entrance and passes the displa window. She looks up for a moment at the words "La Jeunes and at the peculiar trade-mark of the company. It is on t peculiar tradeВ—mark, a geometric figure, that the scene

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is after three o'clock, and the street is alive with children. A covey of them flash past on roller skates, ta by one poor urchin with only one skate, who strives desperately to keep up with the tail end of the processio Mary, coming around the corner, has to draw back half a s to got out of his way. A horseВ—drawn laundry truck stands at the curb on the opposite side of the street, and a man is busily lifting bundles of soiled wash. On the other side Of the street i the Dante. It is an Italian restaurant, a half-flight bel the street level. The name and the word "Restaurant" are written on the glass in gold letters. In the lower left hand corner of the window is a cardboar sign, hand-lettered to read "Rooms for Rent". Above the doorway is a poly-chrome bust of Dante. Mary crosses the street to enter the Dante. A young man, Jason Hoag, comes around the corner. He is a man about thirty-five years ol and rather poorly dressed in an ordinary business suit an trench coat  Under one arm he carries a load of books. He stops and looks at Mary with interest. She continues on, going down the steps, under the Dante statue, and into th restaurant. Jason looks after her.

dialogues.speaker: INT DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: This is a fairly good-sized room, with benches along the walls and many small tables. Along one wall is a crudely painted mural, a reproduction of the famous painting whic shows Dante's first meeting with Beatrice. Dante is passi along the cobbled street, and Beatrice, with two companio large, flourishing wenches, is casting him a coy look ove her shoulder in passing. Directly under the feet of the p is a small table for one patron. On a back counter stands enormous, shining metal coffee machine. This is a patente contraption for making coffee. The entire machine is contrived to serve only one small purpose В—В—to make a c coffee by driving steam through ground coffee. Near this machine and flanking the door into the kitchen are fake p in wooden tubs. There is a door leading to the house hall and through this door we can see the newel post of the stairway leading to the rooms above. On most of the table platters of antipasto have been arranged in readiness for dinner hour. When Mary enters, the restaurant is empty, b echoes to the sound of a rich female voice singing with g sentimental emphasis the words of "Care Mio Ben." Mary lo around, hesitates a moment, and then starts toward the ba of the restaurant, as if following the source of the sing At the swinging door which separates the restaurant from kitchen Mary hesitates a moment, then knocks timidly. The singing continues, and realizing that her knock will not heard above it, Mary shyly pushes open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a cluttered, busy, steaming kitchen. In one corne a little table Mr. Romari, the proprietor, in a waiter's uniform, is busily folding napkins. Mrs. Romari herself f whose bosom come the sounds of "Caro Mio Ben," can be seen through a cloud of steam behi boiling, kettle of spaghetti. She is a tall, gracious Ita of sentiment and humor. Her pet pigeon in close attendanc her feet. This bird follows her wherever she goes, hoppin about the floor at her heels. As Mrs. Romari wants to lif kettle of spaghetti from the stove and carry it to a cent table, she softly kicks the pigeon out on her way with a practiced backward sweep of her slippered foot. Her turn brings her face to face with Mary as she enters. Both the Romaris look at her questioningly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm worry to bother you. I want to ask you about my sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you might know her. She was seen here about a week ago. Her name is Jacqueline Gibson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging) I don't know no Gibson. This is a restaurant. Many people come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's very beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romari shrugs again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could tell you what she looked like -- I know you'd remember her, She is tall --with dark hair --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romari shrugs. This all means nothing to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once you'd seen my sister you'd never forget her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting; to Romari) Giacomo -- la bellisslina madonna В—-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mary) Let me look at you -- you could be her sister

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Yes В—В— yes, if she made that much impression on you, I'm sure it was Jacqueline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not been here for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she was here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, yes. One day a beautiful car comes here. This beautiful lady in furs gets out. There is a handsome man with her, and the chauffeur  The lady rents one of our upstairs rooms. The chauffeur changes the lock on the door. Then the lady never comes back --not to live, anyhow. She came back three, four times, but always alone and just to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary shakes her head in puzzlement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean she just came here, rented the room, locked it, and left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- and pays the rent every month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you let me see that room? If it is hers, there might be something there to help me find my sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) No -- the rent in paid. The lady asked us to promise, I wouldn't open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romari shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Mrs. Romari, pleading) It's important

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Romari looks at her kindly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and the Romaris. It is a bleak hallway with a narrow strip of worn carpet running down the exact middle of the floor space. A picture of St. Francis of Assisi, surround by fluttering white birds, hangs on the wall, a little bi askew. Mrs. Romari and Mary stand near the stairway raili with the pigeon in close attendance on Mrs. Romari. Romar with a toolbox at his feet, is at the door, on which is t number "7". He has taken off the bottom hinge and is now striking a last few blows to remove the pin from the top hinge. As he works, a girl -- Mimi -- crosses in the background one hallway door to another. She is a tall, thin blonde a is wearing a faded bathrobe. She has a handkerchief over lips, and is coughing dismally. She closes the door behin her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fo come ti pare. To desiderare sempre di vedere che cosa c'era in quella stanza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Mrs. Romari) What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (translating) He says he always wanted to see the inside of that room anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The top hinge comes off. Mr. Romari opens the door, and t three press forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA IS SHOOTING OVER the shoulders and PAST the ha lost profiles of Mary and the Romaris, as they look into room. It is a room that is empty except for two objects. a pipe overhead is suspended a hangman's noose and beneat stands a little gilt chair. There is nothing else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT of Jason Hoag. He is standing shyly beside the coffee machine while Mr. Romari draws a cup of the coffee Jason watches Romari while he pulls the various levers, releases the clouds of steam and finally pulls out the li demiВ—tass and puts it on a little tray. While Jason watc he listens to conversation going on nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you, young lady, when a thing like this comes up, you've got to go to the police. What do you think people pay taxes for? I ain't just to keep us chasing after crooks and regulating traffic. We're supposed to help everybody. You gotto go to the police about your sister, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romari starts out of scene with the little cup of coffee. CAMERA PANS with him as he brings the coffee to Mary who seated with Mrs. Romari at one of the tables under the mu A policeman stands beside them. The policeman is in a hea blue sweater, with his coat over his arm, his uniform cap the back of his belt and all the metal weight of his impedimenta can be seen hanging from his belt, handcuffs, revolver, billy, etc. Jason comes hesitantly into the sce He addresses the policeman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had some experience with the Bureau of Missing Persons

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- well, Mr. Hoag, lost persons are the concern of the Missing Persons Bureau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a poet, Jason. You stick to your poetry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a way that makes everything my business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little hesitantly to Jason) Were you going to make a suggestion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I was going to tell you to look into your own heart -- do you really want to find your sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks affronted. Mrs. Romari bursts out laughing in good humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, my Jason -- always laughing -- always trying to help others. (to Mary) He's a good boy, Miss -- he just talks that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a little smile to Mary) I'm a good boy, but no one listens to what I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do what I tell you, young lady, and go to the Missing Persons Bureau for your sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning from Jason to the policeman and starting to rise) If you'll give me the address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT. A long counter divides the room in half. On on side are the filing cabinets, records, and office equipme used by the policemen who service this heartbreak house. Behind the desk, protected by steel wickets, sit half a d policemen taking down dates. CAMERA DOLLIES SLOWLY FORWARD parallel to the counter. As moves along, we hear the voice of the petitioners describ their loved ones. The same flat, unemotional professional voice seems to as the routine questions at each of the different wickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was only sixteen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had she ever run away before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he have on when last seen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tearfully) He went out without his hat or his coat. It's very cold for such an old man -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any identifying marks or characteristics, scars, amputations, tattoo marks, speech impediments?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA DOLLIES UP to the        last wicket where Mary st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any further details?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sold her business about eight months ago to Mrs. Esther Redi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What relation are you to the missing person?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary starts to sign. REVERSE ANGLE - on the other side of the wicket. Two men stand in the f.g., but not together. In the b.g. we see Mary's back as she signs the police report. The man in th center is Paul Radeau, a big man with iron-gray hair. He appears entirely oblivious of everything around him. The second man is Irving August, a skip-trace artist. His derby is dulled by the mists of many winters, and his dark eyes are fastened upon Mary. It is obvious that he h been listening as she made out her report. Mary finishes signing the report and turns away from the wicket. She ta scarcely more than a single step when she finds herself confronted by Irving August, who smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Irving August, private investigator. I think I can help you. Here's my card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He produces a business card which he hands to Mary. Mary takes the card and glances at it as August continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name may not mean anything to you, young lady, but say the word and I'll have your sister for you in forty-eight hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed) You can?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing expansively) Look, sister', Manhattan is only nine miles long and four and one  half miles wide. I ain't never been off it. I know it like you know your own back yard. You get me a small retainer --say fifty bucks, and I'll get your sister for you. I guarantee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't any money but I'll get a job and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irving August's enthusiasm vanishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady, this kind of work costs money. I got to cover all the hospitals, the morgue -- that's the first place you got to go and it ain't pleasant -- the morgue -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finishes his speech by shaking his head. Mary turns aw and goes out of scene. August is standing, staring disgustedly after her when a hand touches him on the shou and he turns to face Paul Radeau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who I am, August?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly tense and cautious) Sure I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you know that if I give you a little advice, it'll be good advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah В—- sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That girl was looking for Jacqueline Gibson. I'd forget it if I were you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Mr. Radeau, it's forgot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Radeau nods appreciatively and goes ponderously away. Irv August watches him go, his eyes sharp with avarice and suspicion. With quick steps, August crosses to the wicket where Mary had given her report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Danny, get me the file on Jacqueline Gibson, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The policeman turns to the file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bulwarks and gangplank are in the f.g. The street and wharf at river level. Beyond that there are the sidewalk the two doors leading into the morgue. The river is not s although the sound of tugboat and barge whistles comes o. The street and sidewalk are wet, as if a drizzling rain h recently fallen, One of these doors is open and from it c a procession of dock workers carrying cheap pine coffins. other door is closed, Above both doors are printed the wo

dialogues.speaker: NEW YORK CITY MORGUE
dialogues.text: Over the door from which the pine boxes are being taken i another legend carved into the stone: HE CALLETH ALL HIS CHILDREN BY THEIR NAME. Out of the second door Mary emerges. Her face is white an drawn. With a shudder she wraps her coat about her and st walking, bracing herself against the fresh, cold gusts of wind blowing from the river. A barge whistle sounds o.s. dismally.

dialogues.speaker: INT RECEPTION ROOM
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT Mary Gibson and Miss Summers, the receptionist, Miss Summers wears hornВ—rimmed glasses and a oriijp whit shirtwaist. In front of her is a plaque with the inscript

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRALTY LAWYERS
dialogues.text: Miss Summers is reading questions from a form reception p and filling out the answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whom do you wish to see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gregory Ward, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what is it about, Miss Gibson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her voice almost a whisper) A personal matter В—В— I was given Mr. Ward's name --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I ask who gave you his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary thinks a moment, and as she thinks all the horror of trip to the morgue and what she has seen        is reflec her face and voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The morgue В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Summers looks up at her in surprise, but already Mar beginning to faint. As she crumples, we IRIS OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IRIS IN on a CLOSEUP of Mary's face as seen through a glass of water which she is sipping, Gregory Ward is hold the glass and over the shot we hear his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you feel all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Gregory Ward seated beside M who is reclining on a couch in his office. He is a man in middle thirties, handsome and wellВ—dressed in a quietly, professional way. He takes the glass away from Mary's lip and passes it to Miss Summers who is beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like an idiot В—В— fainting in a stranger's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Summers, with a considerate look to see that Mary is right, starts out of the room with the glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) We're not exactly strangers, Mary. Jacqueline spoke about you often. I suppose she told you about me,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...At the morgue they told me a Mr. Gregory Ward had made inquiries about Jacqueline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Morgue? No wonder you fainted. (he pauses) I wish you had come to me first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you know where Jacqueline is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head negatively) But I'd give a great deal to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spunkily) Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) I love your sister, Mary. I love her very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a little silence while Mary looks at him steadil then she half smiles. He leans over and pats her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's easy to understand now, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking in a low voice, almost as if to himself) A man would look anywhere for her, Mary. There is something exciting and unforgettable about her -В— something you never get hold of В—- something that keeps a man following after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I loved Jacqueline I thought I knew her. Today I found out such strange things В—В—frightening things. I saw a hangman's noose that she had hanging -В— waiting В—В— I feel as if I'd never known her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) At least I can explain that, Mary. Your sister had a feeling about life В—В— that it wasn't worth living unless one could end it. I helped her get that room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weren't you afraid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afraid she might commit suicide? (he shakes his head) People who commit suicide don't talk about it. That room made her happy in some strange way I couldn't understand. She lived in a world of her own fancy. She didn't always tell the truth. In fact -В— I'm afraid she didn't know what the truth was. (he pauses for a moment, and looks at Mary) There were many things about Jacqueline I didn't understand, and yet, without understanding, I had to be with her В—В— to see her В—В— to touch her В—В— in order to be happy. It's hard to explain to a youngster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little sharply) I'm not a youngster. I can understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The colors returning to your cheeks. You look as if you were coming back to life. Are you sure you didn't faint because you were hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks astonished, and then laughs to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know...I didn't have lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at his wristwatch, and chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nearly six. Time for dinner, I'd say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He extends his hand to her to help her up. She takes it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT CHATSWORTH HOTEL FOR WOMEN
dialogues.text: DOLLY SHOT of Mary and Gregory Ward as they come up along street in front of the hotel. There is a very heavy mist Ward carries an umbrella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. It was a lovely dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) But I reel guilty. It doesn't seem right for me to enjoy myself with Jacqueline gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't make it your life's work looking for Jacqueline. (with a smile) ) You'll have to do other things... live...get some enjoyment out of life. I hope you'll let me help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Thank you.. .goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tips his hat and turns away, as she starts in to the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: TNT LOBBY CHATSWORTH HOTEL
dialogues.text: It is a conventional hotel lobby. Mary comes in, and as s crosses the lobby, flrving August rises from a straight b chair set against a pillar, and comes to meet her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been waitin' for you Miss Gibson. I want you to know I've decided to take your case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. August, I'm not at all sure -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Look. Don't say a word. I've taken an interest in you and I'm willin' to put up my time to help you. Besides, I think I know where to find your sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. This has got a lot of angles. You've got to take it easy. Do you know a Mrs. Redi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. She bought my sister's business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what she told you. I looked it up at the Hall of Records. Your sister deeded her the business as an outright girt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would Mrs. Redi lie to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I tried to find out.        I went to La Jeunesse В—В— (he mispronounces as badly as he can) -- used a phony health inspector's badge В—В— they let me go through the works -- all but one room. That room was locked. I'd like to see the inside of that room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think my sister is there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we go there now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister, you can't just go breaking into places. There's a night watchman down there and locks on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If my sister's in that room, it won't make any difference about warrants- and things, I want to go there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) I don't know if I want to go with you or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary starts out and, a little reluctantly, August follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and August come across tho street and look in the windows of the cosmetic company. Only the night lights ar burning in the salon. August tries the door rather perfunctorily. He shakes his head, and with Mary, moves o the side door leading into the passageway. From his pocke takes a bunch of keys and tries one after another. Finall one key works and the door swings open. Mary stops in ahe of August.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO SHOT of Mary and August. August softly closes the doo behind him. The street light shines through the glass upp ha-if of the door and invades the dark hallway for a shor distance. They walk softly forward to the place where thi light ends abruptly in the darkness. Here Mary pauses. Au looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which room is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the last door at the end of this hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary starts forward a step or two, the shadows closing ar her until only her face is still in the light. August fol her. She stops and looks off into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You scared?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand a moment in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could go on, Mr. August. You could open the door. I'd stay right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: August shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only a little way, Mr. August.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand again silently looking down the dark corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't stand here all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could go and open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Realizing the futility of argument, he breaks off what he going to say, shrugs, and starts down the dark passage. M watches him and retreats a stop or two toward the street order to have the comforting light around her again. She stands there while August's footsteps recede in the darkn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A night watchman, an old man wearing a worn corduroy Norf jacket and a battered hat, with his time clock hanging fr broad strap around his neck, comes out of a neighboring store, a flower shop. He carefully closes the door behind and goes to the entrance of La Jeunesse. From a key ring hanging from the leather clock strap he selects one key a begins to open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary still stands in the patch of light near the doorway. Abreast of her is the doorway leading from the hall to th salon. Through the glass upper half of the door, she sees gleam of light in the other room and tiptoes up to the do and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Mary's angle, shooting through the window, can be so the night watchman, the beam of his flashlight coursing a of him as he makes his way to a time clock. Ho rings in h clock. MED. CLOSE SHOT В— Mary, nervous and apprehensive, looks through at the night watchman. She makes a decision and starts off along the hallway to warn August. She disappea in the blackness of the unlit portion of the hallway. REVERSE SHOT. At the far end of the hallway the illuminat square of the street door can be seen, and the little pat of light near it  Nearer the CAMERA a broad streak of lig from a partially open door is between the darkness and th CAMERA. Mary comes out of tho darkness and into this ligh At the same moment, August comes out of the partially ope door, blocking out the light for a minute. His shadow goe ahead of him - contorted and strange. He stands a moment before Mary; both of his hands clenched tightly against h stomach. She speaks to him in a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. August -- the night watchman

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: August makes no answer, but starts walking blindly, swayi little, toward the street door. Mary goes with him, walki at his side, trying to peer into his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night watchman -- he is in the salon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still August pays no attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. August, what is it? What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no answer. Ho continues to walk in the same jerk painВ—gripped fashion, slowly and unsteadily, toward the light. They are engulfed in the darkness. MED. CLOSE SHOT - August and Mary from the street angle, they come out of the darkness. Mary is very agitated and worried. August still continues to plod blindly forward. reaches out to touch his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. August --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her hand touches his shoulder. Almost as if unable to bea this trifling weight, he collapses suddenly at her foot. looks down. CLOSEUP of Irving August's arm on the floor. It is sprawl awkwardly out  The sleeve is darkly stained, and there is widening stain of blood upon the floor. Mary's slippered step back so that the blood will not touch her. Mary screams. The narrow hallway rings, echoes and reecho with the sound. Mary runs wildly toward the door, fumbles with the knob a pulls it brusquely open. As she does so, the beam of the night watchman's searchlight comes in from the loft. O.S. wild bell starts to ring madly as Mary bolts in panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary comes out of tin deer and starts running down the street. Behind her the lights of both the hall and the sa blaze. The bell rings o.s. she looks ever her shoulder an continues running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, still running, comes down the street. She looks bac for a moment and then goes down the stairs to the subway. The CAMERA REMAINS on the subway entrance a moment so tha can be clearly seen that this entrance is marked:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is late, and this particular car is almost empty. Ther Mary, .sitting huddled in one corner under the map of the route which the I.R.T. so thoughtfully provides. Mary sit still and white, obviously shaken. Her coat collar is dra protectively against her throat. Opposite her are a pair young lovers, their hands clasped, who look blissfully in each others eyes. The conductor comes shambling into the car. He leeks at M and takes a step toward her, teetering on practiced tees, disdaining the overhead strap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where you're going, lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been to the end of the line and back again -- hope you enjoyed the ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He passes on. Mary looks after him, frightened. As he rea the end of the car, the subway train begins to come to a step. The two lovers get up, their hands still tightly clasped. INSERT A SIGN reading:        "14TH STREET" BACK TO SCENE. The train comes to a stop. Mary glances up The subway door glides open. The two lovers sidle crab-wi through it, never relinquishing their clasps on each othe hands, and through this same door come three men, three convivial drunks. GROUP SHOT of the three drunks as they seat themselves opposite Mary. The middle drunk carries the heaviest load The ether two support him, laughing and rearing as they m him comfortable between them. All three wear top hats and dark overcoats  The hat of tin man in the middle is tilte over one eye. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Mary as she looks at the three men acr from her. Over this shot comes the sound of the subway tr stopping. THREE SHOT of the three men. One of them leans across the supposedly drunken man between them to offer a light for ether's cigarette. The man in the middle lolls awkwardly, swaying- between them. CLOSEUP of Mary as she stares at the man in the middle. S familiar chord of memory is touched in her mind. THREE SHOT of the three men. . The car jolts and the hat slides off the middle man's head. We see that the man is Irving August, and that he is dead. One of the men quickl reaches down, picks up the hat and puts it back on August head. CLOSEUP of Mary. Her fear is confirmed. Looking around he cautiously, she gets up and starts down the aisle. At the of the car she leeks back. FULL SHOT - the three men sitting at the opposite end of car. One of the men is whispering to the other man pointi to Mary. FULL SHOT of Mary as she quickly opens the door and goes the next car. She walks down the length of the car. A man sleeping. She shakes his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please --- please В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man only mutters something in his sleep. Mary continu down the car's length to where a drunken girl sits, her h lolling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want your help, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drunken woman merely looks at her blankly. The cars a coming to a stop again. The door opens and the conductor comes through. Mary seizes his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These men in there В—В— don't let them get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of them has been murdered!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conductor looks at her dubiously. The cars have come stop. He looks into the next car and then glances down at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crossly) What men?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary turns and looks back toward the car she just left. LONG SHOT of the car as Mary sees it. It is completely deserted. TWO SHOT        - Mary and the conductor. The subway trai starting to move again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they were there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conductor looks at her and merely observes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT of a newspaper vender calling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wuxtra! Murder! Murder! Read all about it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is standing directly in front of the revolving doors a behind him, through the glass of the doorway, we can see waiting, her face anxious and strained as she peers out o the street. A constant stream of passersby goes by the building. Out of this stream Gregory Ward emerges, goes through the revolving doors, and we see him met by Mary, begins excitedly to talk to him. He shakes his head, take her arm and walks her off.

dialogues.speaker: INT COFFEE COUNTER
dialogues.text: This is a very small counter and stand with a few tables the window -- the sort of restaurant that is open only fo breakfast and lunch and is patronized by office workers w can content themselves with a sandwich and a cup of coffe The scene opens on the newsboy as he comes into the restaurant and goes up to the counter. The waiter behind counter buys a paper and brings it with an order of one c of coffee and a glass of milk to Mary and Ward, who are sitting at a small table. The newsboy goes on outside and over the scene from time to time we hear his voice crying "Murder! Read all about it!" Gregory Ward takes the glass of milk and slides it down t counter in front of Mary. He opens up the paper and scans carefully. Mary watches him anxiously, and turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is about another murder В—В— a woman at Fifty Second Street

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you do believe me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a little pause) The important thing is, the police won't believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw him on the floor. He was cut -В— (indicates her own belly) --here. The blood was running out. He was dead. I'm sure of it.  Then on the subway I saw him В—В— white В—В— and the men holding him up between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory takes a sip of his coffee and speaks gently, but unable to hide his disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course В—В— but the police would say you'd probably had a bad dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a kind little man in his way В—В— and I made him go down that hall into the darkness. I made him do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink your milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks up, startled at this note of command.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like to be ordered to do anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory looks at her for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I didn't intend to treat you like a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you have treated me that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't do it again. We're friends. I'll never order you about again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts out his hand and Mary takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) However, I won't say that I'll not take charge occasionally, and I'm going to take charge new. I've a job for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me you were pretty good with youngsters. Today I bumped into an old friend of mine, Mrs.  Wheeler  She runs a settlement house down in the Village and is looking for a kindergarten teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not much money, but it's enough to live on. You'd have to move out of that hotel and into a furnished room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe the Romaris might have a room. They seem nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people at the restaurant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory starts getting up, looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want, I've time to take you down to see Mrs. Wheeler right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary gets up. They stay for a moment while he gets change of his pocket and gives it to the counter man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark, handsome man with bold, insolent eyes lounges carelessly before the reception desk. Miss Summers puts d the phone and smiles up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Ward will see you in just a few minutes. Won't you wait, Dr. Judd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out his cigarette case, selects a cigarette, but no matches. Miss Summers gives him her lighter. He lights cigarette and crosses the room to sit down on the waiting room couch. Throughout the scene he toys with the lighter his hand. Miss Summers looks across et him for a moment, then, after a little hesitancy, she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Judd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Dr. Louis Judd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read your book. The one in which you wrote about the cure for drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a dipsomaniac at your age?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's my father -- I wanted to talk to you -- you wrote about cures --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd silences her by raising his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I don't practice any more. I find it easier to write about mental illness and leave the cure of it to others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The buzzer sounds and Miss Summers brings the phone recei to her ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up from the phone) Mr. Ward is free now, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd gets up and saunters toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he walks) There are any number of other psychiatrists who can help your father -- dipsomania is rather sordid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles charmingly at her, and deliberately pockets her lighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he goes through the door, disappointment in her voice) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches for a cigarette, then realizes that Judd has usurped her lighter. With a blank expression, she turns a looks at the closed door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Judd comes in and walks calmly across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he crosses) I've come from Jacqueline. She needs money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you told me you didn't know where she was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sprawling into) (a chair) I didn't. She came to me a few days ago. To put it delicately her care imposes a financial burden upon me. She thought you might lighten that burden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Jacqueline wants money she can come to me herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid she can't do that, Ward. It would endanger her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sort of danger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to tell you. I would tell you, but I'm fond of Jacqueline, I don't want her to run any risks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is nonsense! Unless I know where Jacqueline is, and how she is, I won't give you any money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost musingly) You're a curious man. You're willing to jeopardize Jacqueline's life in order to satisfy your own curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come to me with some wild story about her being in danger - naturally I want to know what kind of danger. I want to know where she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory Ward rises and starts around the desk toward Dr. Judd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not just for myself I'm asking. Her sister is here. The kid's half crazy with anxiety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a man, you distrust me В—- perhaps you believe me as a physician.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd looks coolly at Gregory and Gregory nods grudgingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then I can tell you that in addition to other dangers, there is a grave danger of Jacqueline losing her sanity. I would advise against you seeing her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why? She's been ill --erratic, but I've never heard of anything like that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you I was speaking as her physician -- not as anything else -- You can believe me or not, just as you choose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory looks at him a moment, then turns and sits down i his chair with an air of resignation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily) How much does she want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She could use a hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making a motion toward his desk) I'll give you a check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) She can only use cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ward takes out a billfold and examines its contents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't got that much in cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much have you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About forty-five dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the time being, I imagine that must do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ward, frowning, hands over the money reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, how is Jacqueline?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) Oh, as beautiful as ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But tell me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging) She's nervous, naturally, under the circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What circumstances?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd has reached the door. He turns and grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that I can't tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to open the door, pauses and looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insolently, with the door half open) As her physician and I am speaking as her friend now, too, I warn you that it would be extremely dangerous to attempt to see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door closes behind Judd. Ward stands for a moment loo at the closed door, then crosses resolutely to a halltree the corner, takes his hat and coat and strides out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the rest hour and the children are lying in a neat on the floor, each wrapped in his own little blanket. In middle of the row, one black-haired little girl keeps pok up her head to watch Mary and Gregory Ward. Ward, with hi overcoat on, and hat in hand, is seated on the corner of Mary's desk, his back to the children, talking to her. Ma sits at her desk watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What brought you down here, Greg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little evasively) Oh, I had business with a man... but I missed him -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm glad you came to see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little girl in the center of the room sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I wake up now, Miss Gibson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You first have to go to sleep, Nancy. Then you can wake up. (to Gregory) We'll have to talk quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ward turns to look around the bright, sunny room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything has turned out so well for me - - I have a nice job -- friends - - except the one thing I came to New York for - -to find Jacqueline --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not knowing that makes it so hard. This way, whenever I walk along the streets I think I see her. I see some woman, peer into her face and find a stranger. I dream of her at night. It's terrible to say -- but if she were dead it would be easier. There would be some certainty about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ward patiently pats her shoulder, and looks at her with understanding and sympathy. They face each other for a mo In the b.g. Nancy again rises from her neat fold of blank

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Gibson, I'm tired of resting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sh-h-h Nancy. The other children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy gives her a dirty look and subsides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning) (back to Ward) What have you done about Irving August?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little guiltily) Oh, I'm making investigations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never believed a word I told you about Mr. August.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Mary, now that I know you better, I think I can be more frank with you. I don't believe you. I still can't understand the reason for such a wild tale. It's like some of Jacqueline's stories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg, it isn't a wild tale. It's true. If there were only some way --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a very simple way. Got a telephone book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary reaches into her desk drawer and pulls out the New Y telephone directory. He takes it and thumbs through it rapidly, then dials. While he is doing this, Nancy pokes her head again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it fifteen minutes yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Nancy.        You've got to sleep two more minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy lets herself relax on the hard floor in quiet desperation. By this time Ward has finished dialing his number. Someone has evidently answered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) May I speak to Mr. Irving August?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the telephone comes the sound of unintelligible conversation in an explanatory note. Ward listens, frowni

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) I'm very sorry. Thank you..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up the receiver and turns to Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were right. Irving August has been missing for three weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is saying good-bye to the children. They are being called for by their mothers. Most of the women are Italia Irish, Bohemian or Jewish New York women who collect thei offspring and move out with them through the little wicke gate. The children are carrying bits of childish craft wh they have manufactured during the day - paper baskets, crayola drawings. Each of the children shows off what he done during the day to his fond mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama, see. Miss Gibson helped me. It's a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful. We show it to papa tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Michele eat her soup today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's been an angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little boy comes running out of the building. He is the last and is late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Mama. Wait for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drop seat of his little suit is hanging open. Mary ru after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angelo. Wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She catches up with him, buttons his suit, gives him a playful pat on the bottom, and he runs after the others. turns to reВ—enter the nursery when Mrs. Wheeler comes ou Mrs. Wheeler is a middleВ—aged woman with a generous, ben smile on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mary, aren't you the popular one. You've a visitor again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary turns to walk toward the building with Mrs. Wheeler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Ward?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not this time. It's a gentleman called Judd -- Dr. Judd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know anyone by that name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He asked for you, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two women go beck into the building.

dialogues.speaker: TNT. DAY NURSERY CLASSROOM
dialogues.text: Judd, wearing a dark overcoat and carrying his hat, is walking up and down. The door opens and Mary comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Judd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss Gibson. I've come to take you to your sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary stops, startled, and looks at him. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be so amazed. It's a very ordinary matter. I'm Jacqueline's physician... Mr. Ward told me you were in town and Jacqueline has sent me to bring you to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where she is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling even more broadly) If I didn't know where she was, could I take you to her? Get your hat and coat. We haven't much time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts for the door, stumbles over a toy. Mary looks d at his feet. He catches the glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my cloven hoof. It trips me up sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cloven hoof?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. You know the devil and all his minions are marked that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks at him in astonishment as they exit through th door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a marble, gilt, and plaster horror of the General Grant rococo period. Glass and gilt iron doors give entra to the hallway, which is floored with soiled marble slabs either side of the hall twin stairs rise to the apartment above, going upward with an accompaniment of gilt iron handrails. Some mail boxes, a worn velvet bench, and moth eaten moose head complete this charming and delicate interior. A young woman is laboriously getting a baby carriage out under one of the stairways and stowing her infant safely its wicker hold. She has tucked him In, steered the carri out from behind the stairway, and is crossing the hallway when the door opens to admit Judd and Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding the door open for Mary) It's amid such marble splendors as these that Jacqueline dwells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can take either stairway -- I prefer the left В—- the sinister side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go toward the left and start ascending the left stairway.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY IN FRONT OF JUDD'S APT- AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Mary and Judd come up the stairs. Judd is fumbling for a He goes to his door, inserts the key, twists it and swing the door open, allowing Mary to precede him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a cheap, furnished apartment. An Aubusson carpet is the floor. The furniture is Grand Rapids Sheraton and the pictures on the wall are representative of hotel art at i worst, colored prints showing French canals, poplar trees old towers. An incongruous picture, however, a huge chrom an ornate fretwork frame dominates one wall. This is the famous picture of the guardian angel which shows a little child, gowned in white, who is about to fall over a preci wore it not for the benign hand of her guardian angel, a figure complete with white robe and white wings. Under th picture is a bureau. It has been converted to a writer's needs by the simple expedient of removing one drawer and reВ—inserting it so that the bottom of the drawer can be as a base for a typewriter. On this overturned drawer sta portable typewriter, a box full of paper, some loose manuscript and a marmalade jar full of pencils. Between a pair of bookends are about four volumes with the author's name В— Louis Judd В— plainly evident on the dust jackets are the only books in the room. At the end of the room is small, useless sort of desk. This has been made into a dressing table by putting a fitted toilet case on top and opening it. Through a double doorway, without doors, can seen a square cubicle containing an unmade bed. Mary come into this room and looks around anxiously. Judd follows h carefully bolts the door behind him and puts it on the ch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling softly) (toward bedroom) Jacqueline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no answer and he strides across the room and loo in. He turns back to Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with genuine surprise) She's not here. She's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks around her a little apprehensive at the though being alone with this stranger. However, his own nervousn at Jacqueline's absence is very genuine. As Mary crosses room to the desk he continues to talk excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why she left. She knows she shouldn't have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary takes a hand mirror out of the fitted case and holds up. A big swirling monogram on the back is immediately visible. The letters are: "J. G." Mary puts it down. In a little ash tray beside the dressing case a cigarette is smoldering. Mary points to it. Judd looks at it, then qui crosses the room to a door obviously leading to a bathroo He knocks, and receiving no answer, opens it and turns ba to the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's gone. She's left me to meet them alone. I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary stands looking at him, amazed at this sudden transit the almost palpable fear of this smooth, easy, sneering m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) What makes you so nervous, Dr. Judd. Who are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd pays no attention to her. He walks quickly to the ot end of the room, then turns to face her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stay here. I'll have to leave you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without any further word he strides quickly to the entran door, fumbles furiously with the chain and lock; opens it goes out, closing the door behind him. Mary stands in the center of the room, completely at a lo She turns back to the desk and snuffs out the cigarette thoughtfully. Again she examines the mirror or some other article in the dressing case, As she stands there, lookin her sister's initials, there is a soft knock at the door. Mary crosses the room quickly and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: TNT. HALLWAY OUTSIDE JUDD'S APT.
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT - Jacqueline Gibson, dressed for the stre in a mink coat and a smart fur toque to match; an impress beautiful, unforgettable woman, stands in this mean hallw TWO SHOT - Mary and Jacqueline in doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from doorway) Jacqueline!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline lifts her hand and puts her forefinger stealth across her lips to indicate silence. They stand facing ea other this way for a single, breathing moment. Then sudde Jacqueline pulls the door shut.

dialogues.speaker: TNT. JUDD'S APT.
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT of Mary, surprised and shocked by this sudden move, stands stockВ—still for half a second. Then she rou herself. She starts tugging at the door. She gets it open starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary comes out into the hall, looks first toward the left stairway. There is no one there. REVERSE SHOT. Apparently Mary looks to the right and agai sees that the hallway and the head of the second flight o stairs is empty. She hesitates for a moment and then star off to the right.

dialogues.speaker: TNT. FLANDERS APT. STAIRWAY
dialogues.text: Mary runs down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: TNT. FOYER
dialogues.text: Mary comes down the stairs. The foyer is empty. She cross to the other stairs and looks up, sees no one, turns and out the street door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary comes out and looks up and down the street. The stre is empty except for a few men passing by. She stands for moment, the wind blowing her skirt against her legs and tugging at her hair. She turns and goes back into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary comes in and starts to mount the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary comes up to the hallway. The door of the apartment i still open. She turns and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary reВ—enters the room. She goes over to the dressing t where she had left her purse and picks it up. As she does this something in the mirror attracts her attention, and look of terror comes into her face. In the mirror can be the back of a large chair near the bureau. Over the top o this chair floats a rising column of cigar smoke. Mary tu ANOTHER ANGLE. A man enters from the left of the scene an seizes Nary's arm. From the armchair another man rises. I Paul Radeau, the man with Irving August at the Missing Persons Bureau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Radeau) Is this her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. (turning to Mary, removing his cigar from his mouth) Where's Jacqueline Gibson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened) I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was just here. Where's she gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's funny. You went out with her, came back alone, and don't know where she went.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause while Radeau studies her and Mary's cour comes back to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you want Jacqueline? What right have you to question me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Radeau pulls an official looking document from his pocket

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young lady, I've got all the right in the world. I'm Paul Radeau, private investigator, and I have been hired to find your sister by her husband, Gregory Ward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP of Mary's face as the full realization of what he said comes to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost in a whisper) Husband --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The restaurant is full, cheerful and noisy with the merry sound of people eating, drinking and talking. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Jason Hoag seated at the feet of Dante small quarto volume is opened at his left hand and he is reading as he eats his antipasto. Without looking he take the last forkful from the plate scrabbles about with his for another forkful but finds only emptiness, and he turn his attention from his book to his plate. He puts down hi fork and looks off beyond the camera, calling out at the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Italian) What ho, wench! Would you keep a benighted traveller waiting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVERSE SHOT - kitchen door. Mrs. Romari, a beaming smile her face, comes from the kitchen bearing an enormous plat of spaghetti. She weaves her way through the tables, hold the platter high over the heads of the customers. She pas a table at which Mary is seated with Gregory Ward. As it wall table, they sit side by side.
