Both look miserable, t faces averted, Gregory is talking eagerly to Mary's turnedВ—away profile. Mrs. Romari passes them and advance toward the table where Jason sits. MED. CLOSE SHOT - Jason at his table. Mrs. Romari the scene beaming, puts the platter on the        table b Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Italian) Jason, my pet В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bella Romari        If I were not seated, I would embrace you in three movements like a sonata. (in very bad Italian) Ah, my wonderful one. Fly with me tonight. We will take your coffee machine and live with the gypsies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Romari giggles with delight and translates Jason's atrocious Italian to two maiden ladies who are gawking at this unrestrained conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Italian) Oh, this funny man. (in English) He is a very funny man, but I love him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While she is talking, Jason has been appreciatively sniff the aroma of the spaghetti. As she turns back to him, he points to his wine glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you thinking of, Bella? Can I eat dry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the wine. I have forgotten the wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Romari goes toward the kitchen. The CAMERA DOLLIES WITH her. As she passes the table wher Gregory and Mary are sitting, the CAMERA STOPS, FOCUSING them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Mary, just because I kept a secret from you doesn't make me a monster. Please look at me, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary pays no attention, but busies herself by taking a si water and pretends to be very interested in Mrs. Romari's further progress through the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't I make you understand? The secret wasn't mine in the first place. It was Jacqueline's. I don't know why. She never wanted anything from me -- not even my name В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary still looks obstinately away. Gregory shakes his hea pauses, and then goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please В—- I can't explain things like this to your right ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night in this very restaurant Mr. Jason Hoag paid a very pretty compliment to my right ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Who the devil is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A poet. He's sitting right over there. That's his table В—В— the one at the feet of Dante.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She half turns to indicate Jason's position. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Jason. He sees Mary looking toward him smiles and nods to her. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Mary and Gregory. Mary nods back to Ja

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking off at Jason) He seems all right. (then resuming his former conversation) Look, Mary. It was something I couldn't tell you. Remember how you came to my office that first day, frightened and broken up? I asked you if she had spoken about me. You said "no." Then how could I tell you that we were married -- and afterwards -- I couldn't tell you because --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Romari comes past them.. She is carrying a bottle of Chianti. She smiles at Mary as she passes, but Mary is to absorbed in her own thoughts to see her. The CAMERA DOLLIES WITH Mrs. Romari. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Jason. Mrs. Romari comes into the scen and starts pouring a glass of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in bad Italian) Why do you bring me wine, beautiful ones when you yourself are intoxicating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs  Romari laughs heartily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in English) You're my favorite audience, Bella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Romari has finished pouring the wine. She puts the w bottle on the table and is about to start off toward the kitchen when she catches a glimpse of Gregory and Mary. Mary's face is still averted from Gregory and both of the look dreadfully unhappy. MED. SHOT of Jason and Mrs. Romari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't everyone be happy like we are -- laugh and have good times. Look at that poor little one В— so sad because she can't find her sister. And that man with her -В— he doesn't make her laugh В—В— he just sits and talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost seriously) We are happy, Mrs. Romari, because you have everything В—В— and I am happy because I have nothing to lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you should make her laugh, Jason. Come, make jokes for her. I'll bring your food to their table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Jason can protest she has leaned over and taken hi plate. MED. SHOT - Mary and Gregory. Their relative positions ha not changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could have told me any time you were Jacqueline's husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things changed, Mary. The reasons for finding Jacqueline changed. I want to find Jacqueline to settle things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled, turns for the first time to Ward) What things? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is at this moment and before he can answer that Mrs. Romari comes into the scene leading Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two are so sad. Your food will not digest, and your wine will sour. You must laugh to eat well. I have brought Jason to make you laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks at Ward. He is obviously annoyed at this interruption. She, too, wishes that Mrs. Romari and Jason not interrupted, but feels it incumbent upon her to be gracious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoag, this is Mr. Ward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men shake hands. Ward with the air of one making empty invitation, hoping that Jason will not accept, indicates the char on the opposite side of the table. Jason stands smiling for a moment, completely aware of th situation and uncertain as to whether to accept or take himself off. Mrs. Romari settles the matter by pulling ou the chair and forcing him to seat himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down. I'll get the rest of your dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm under orders to make you laugh. In Mrs. Romari's mind my poetry and humor have some strange affinity which they don't have in fact. She wants me to play the fool for you, and suddenly, Miss Gibson, I feel as sad as you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Well,then I have spoiled your dinner -- "your food won't digest, and your wine will sour."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will have to make all the jokes, because I'm going to be very serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses, and the two look rather questioningly at him a this preamble. He looks first at one and then at the othe before speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to find your sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that's a good subject for jokes, Mr. Hoag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm not joking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be ridiculous. For months I've had the best private detective in New York looking for Miss Gibson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm better than a detective. I have an understanding of people - and a love of them -- an understanding of the city - -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't even know Jacqueline Gibson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I understand her. That may be more important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It may make very fine poetry, Mr. Hoag, but it doesn't make good sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason turns to Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, when you first came here, I told you to look into your heart. You didn't listen to me. You listened to the policeman instead. You didn't find your sister, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protesting) Look here, just because Mrs. Romari asked you to amuse us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason rises and takes Mary's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This city is my world. I know every rat-infested corner of my world and every starlit chamber of its purity and greatness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He half draws Mary to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't even know where to start - -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason takes Mary along with him, starting for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One starts by beginning. Beginnings lead to an end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ward is forced to rise and go with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason and Ward with Mary between them, cross the street toward the north side of Washington Mews. To their right the mews, the little houses one next to the other in an orderly row. They stop for a moment at the street corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disregarding his question) This is the part of New York I love. It is old. It has memories. If you listen, the houses will speak to you. Walt Whitman...Edna St. Vincent Millay... Eugene O'Neill...in their time they've all lived here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes on to the next house and they follow. The CAMERA DOLLIES WITH them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All very nice but, what are you going to do - listen at every house in New York for Jacqueline's voice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if it explained everything) I'm looking for a party -- a merry party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's illuminating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even Mary looks concerned and puzzled. They have stopped before the next house and again Jason has taken the attit of one listening. The sound of a violin can be heard play Abenlied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only music. It leads, but we cannot follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts off again. Ward and Mary follow him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Riddles now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By this time they have come to the third house and again Jason has paused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. This is a party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from interior of house) Now, if you'll all take your seats, Miss Randall will show us the slides she took of Woods Hole Marine Institute this summer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds dull, doesn't it? My ear is perfectly trained. I can tell the brand of liquor and the quality of the guests from the noise they make.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the next house comes the sound of revelry, laughter a burst of jazz music from a phonograph which obscures th milder noises of the house in front of which they stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly) That sounds more like it. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs hold of Mary's hand and draws her along. They go to the door. Ward follows them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT of Natalie Cortez. She is seated at a small ca table, shuffling a pack of cards with one hand, and surrounded by a small group of her guests in evening clot Natalie is a very beautiful woman of early middle age. It apparent why she uses only one hand to shuffle her cards. has but one arm. A        little cape of gold lame covers shoulders and hangs down over the missing arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shuffle the cards well, Natalie. This is a trick of telepathy not card manipulation

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER SHOT of the same group to include Judd, who stand little distance away with his back purposely turned to th card table. Mrs. Cortez is finishing shuffling the cards. door knocker sounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now pass me the cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The knocker sounds again and Mrs. Cortez hands the cards Gladys, a big, gushy girl, full of hormones and cocktail

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) Gladys, you hand the deck to Louis while I answer the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gladys takes the cards and crosses to Judd, who still sta with his back to his audience, while Mrs. Cortez turns an walks in the other direction. REVERSE SHOT - toward the door. For the first time Mrs. Cortez' living quarters can be seen. The house was former stable on the Mews and in remodeling it for living purpos Mrs. Cortez has allowed the stalls and general architectu of the stable to remain. She uses one of the two stalls a little dining nook, although above it the name of the hor "Apocalypse" is still printed on a placard. The next stal has been converted into a little escritoire, and over thi stall is the name "Morning Star." The place is lit with electrified stable and carriage lamps and furnished with harness and horse adornments which contrast with the rich piled carpet, the lovely square piano of rosewood and the beautiful modern prints with plain wood frames. Book shel cover the largest portion of the walls. Mrs. Cortez wends her way through little groups of her gu and goes to the door. MED. CLOSE SHOT of the door as Mrs. Cortez opens it revea Mary, Ward and Jason on the threshold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason! How nice to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking her hand) I have brought some friends, Natalie. May we all come to your party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs,. Cortez, Mary Gibson and Mr. Ward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mary) It's so nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason has been looking about trying to peer over the head various other guests. Suddenly he turns back to Mrs. Cort and Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ANGLE - Jason emerges between two groups of peopl The CAMERA PICKS him up and DOLLIES WITH him up to the gr around Judd. Judd has turned and is facing them with the cards in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Freeman, yours was the Jack of Spades. Gladys, yours was the Seven of Diamonds, and Mrs. Gosden, the Queen of Hearts -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a murmur of admiration from the little group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you ever do it, Louis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason makes his way through the group and faces Judd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason takes his arm and draws him away a few feet from th group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) Where is Jacqueline Gibson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) What a peculiar question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you with her last week. I knew you'd be here tonight. Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear fellow, it's neither your business to ask, nor mine to tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to move away. Jason takes his arm again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. Look over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He half turns so that Judd faces the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See that girl? That's Jacqueline's sister. It's because of her I ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why come to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because there was another girlВ— years ago -- a nice girl. She lived on Barrow Street. I saw her with you once -В— I saw her with you twice and then I never saw her again. That's why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was my patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was she to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that you would understand if I told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I understand without your telling me. I know something of your history, Jason. I know that you haven't written for ten years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've lost my knack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After that wonderful first book В—- after all the adulation and the good reviews?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have given anything if I could have written that book. You had all my admiration and respect В— once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT - Mary, Mrs. Cortez and Ward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that you know me, you must feel free to come often.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over this shot comes the sound of Jason's voice calling M Mary smiles at Mrs. Cortez and looks off. LONG SHOT from Mary's ANGLE of the group around Judd and Jason. Jason is beckoning to her. THREE SHOT - Mary, Mrs. Cortez and Ward. Mary gives Mrs. Cortez a smile of apology and starts toward Jason. Ward t her arm to lead her through the party throng. MED. CLOSE SHOT - the group around Jason and Judd as Mary Ward come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imperturbably) Hello, Ward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes a half bow to Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Miss Gibson --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is at this point that Gladys comes bursting back. She picks up the name "Gibson" and rushes ever to Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gibson? Are you Jacqueline's sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Do you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not letting her finish) Know her! My dear, we were intimate! The times we used to have together! I bet she never told you about that -- you're too young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid you don't understand. Miss Gibson's sister is missing В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missing? Well, no wonder. When she took up with Louis Judd she went out of circulation, like that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She snaps her fingers. Mary looks from Judd to Ward. The two men stare fixedly at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mary) My dear, have I said something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gladys in a low voice) No. You've just turned the dagger in the wound - - a beautiful job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks quickly over to Mary, sees tears coming to her e takes her elbow and leads her to another part of the room Gladys' attention is attracted by laughter from another g of the party and she drifts off. Ward and Judd are left together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ward) There are too many people here. I think Jacqueline may be lonely --? for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd grins. He wanders off. Gregory stands scowling after him. TWO SHOT - Jason and Mary. They have seated themselves in little breakfast nook built in the horses' stall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, Mary, I'm not quite a fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least you knew about Dr. Judd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you knew he'd be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. And now that I've shown you that I know that much, and can guess more -- will you trust me to look for Jacqueline?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to look for Jacqueline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her hand across the table and holds it firmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a terrible failure, Mary, -- a book clerk by day and a poet by night, and not a very good one - but if you'll trust me -- at this one thing I won't fail --I'll find your sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT of Jason leaning on a file counter in the libr Beside him is an enormous file of cards and right under h nose, two pretty white hands ruffle the cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (admiringly) You have such lovely hands, Miss Gottschalk. So slim and capable --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PULLS BACK to show us Miss Gottschalk. The fac doesn't match the hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gurgling) Oh, Mr. Jason. I really shouldn't be doing this, you know. It's against the rules. (curiously) When did you say you wanted them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see what they read so I'll know what kind of books to give my friends as presents. There's nothing nicer for a gift than a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was the first one -- Mrs. Redi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ruffling through the cards) N - o - p - q - r - r - Redi. Here it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the card out of the file and hands it to Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the other was Judd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Dr. Louis Judd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's here, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands it over to Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it be asking too much, Miss Gottschalk, for you to get me these books?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gurgling again) No, not at all, Mr. Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the cards and glances at the numbers and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coyly) Why, Mr. Jason. Most of these books are on the closed shelf. You have to get permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (using Miss Gottschalk's tone) I wouldn't want to take them out. I just want to look at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relenting) Well, since, you're over twenty oneВ—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giggling, she turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason comes up the stairs whistling. As he reaches the landing, Mimi comes out of her door at the end of the corridor and goes across to the bathroom. She is in her soiled dressing gown, her hair lank about her shoulders. carries a towel over one arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waving to her) Mimi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns toward him and is about to speak when a fit of coughing takes her. She passes on, goes through the doorw to the bath. Jason goes on to a door halfway down the hal #lO. He knocks on the door. Mary's voice can be heard bid him enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason turns the knob and throws the door open. Through th open door Mary's room can be seen. It is a small, dismal cubicle like the room with the noose. There is a day bed, dresser, a little desk, an armchair, an oldВ— fashioned r and light curtains at the window. There are a few oddВ—sh pillows on the day bed and some other evidences of Mary's attempts to make this place bright and livable. On the dresser top stands a large framed photograph of Jacquelin As the door opens, Mary can be seen washing a pair of whi gloves in a little basin set in the corner of the room. As the scene progresses,, she can be seen washing the glo on her hands, removing them, rinsing out the soap and the tacking them up on the open window sash to dry. Jason pul rose from his pocket. A withered blossom. He offers it. M holds up her white-gloved hands to indicate that she can' take the flower. He picks up a tumbler, fills it with wat puts the rose in it, and sets the whole mess on the windo sill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's terribly sweet of you, Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have something even better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fishes through his pockets and brings out a ragged wor piece of paper; crossing over to her he carefully smooths this paper beside the wash basin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT        THE PARALLELOGRAM traced on thin paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A parallelogram with a split triangle in its very center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But for what, Jason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To unlock mysteries -- to unravel the thread that leads to Jacqueline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks helpless and bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with mock patience) I suppose I'll have to explain. Go on with your washing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seats himself on the edge of the day bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been at the library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're always at the library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went as a detective. I found out that Mrs. Redi reads the same books as Dr. Judd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that's so revealing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But who is Judd, a psychiatrist. It's quite natural that he should read books on the history of old religious societies. But why should Mrs. Redi, a woman with a beauty parlor --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. And this figure --she traced it. The book I saw at the library had been marked "perfect" by the library inspector in March. Mrs. Redi had it out in April. No one else had read it since.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) I'm at sea, Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with even more patience) Such a simple matter. This figure is the symbol of the Palladists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly mocking) It's all clear to me now -- so clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it would be, but just to be sure, I'll tell you that the Palladists are a society of Devil worshippers --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Devil worshippers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. I'm serious. It's a real and vary earnest society -- a dangerous society...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still laughing) I can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some time before those nice white gloves are dry you're going to go and find out a few things about Mrs. Redi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary chuckles to herself and, taking up one of the gloves blows into it, laughing in spite of herself as she does s In a playful mood, she brushes the blown-up glove against back of Jason's neck. He starts nervously. Like a young child, Mary is thrown into a fit of laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jason, I scared you. Maybe I could scare some information out of Mrs. Redi or perhaps Frances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs gaily.

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH AT LA JEUNESSE COSMETICS, INC.
dialogues.text: This is a mirror shot. In the glass Mary can be seen seat in the chair with Frances Fallon behind her brushing her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't see much fun in teaching school. Why don't you go into the beauty business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I like teaching school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if it's fun for you, it's all right. I get a kick out of my work when the customers aren't too crabby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Mrs. Redi nice to work for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redi's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She seems rather an odd woman to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a pretty good sort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does she do with herself after business hours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It always seemed to me she was sort of lonely and unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess most people are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances finishes brushing her hair and pats it into place

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Mary gets up and collects her handbag and other belongings, Frances makes out the check and hands it to M

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the old days, it would have been on the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary hands her a coin which Frances refuses, pushing her away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tip is, anyhow. I like to work on your hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary takes a piece of paper from her bag and shows it to Frances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what this is, Frances?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling broadly) I ought to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances reaches back of her, takes a bottle of La Jeuness perfume and holds it up to Mary. INSERT        BOTTLE OF LA JEUNESSE PERFUME. On the front the parallelogram with split triangle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over shot) It's Mrs. Redi's new trademark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, I should have known. That figure has been puzzling me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She passes into the main portion of the salon and Frances follows her. Mrs. Redi, passing by, stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mary. It's nice to see you. No news of Jacqueline?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary goes on toward the cashier's desk, and pays her chec As Mrs. Redi and Frances stand talking, Mary gets her cha and leaves in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing! That's absurd. I heard you laughing and talking, She was asking questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was just asking about you - Whether it was nice to work for you or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that was all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. She asked about the trademark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she want to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She showed me a drawing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in anger) You        fool! That symbol is us -- us. She was asking about us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks off toward the door opening on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'll stop her questions В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd, dressed in a dressing gown, is seated on the straig chair before the makeshift desk, talking with Mrs. Cortez is dressed in street clothes and who has perched herself the arm of a large, overstuffed chair. They have evidentl been talking for some time. The scene opens with a slight lull in the conversation, while Judd takes a cigarette an lights it, blows out the first inhalation of smoke and lo squarely at Mrs. Cortez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the others -- Redi, Fallon, Leo, Bruns. But I would never have guessed it of you, Natalie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (airily) One believes -В— it's like any other religion...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd hardly describe It that way В—- The worship of evil is a pretty dreadful and special thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems right to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the theory behind the movement. If one believes in good one believes in evil. If one believes in God, one must believe in the devil. And an intelligent person can make his own choice В—В— that's it, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you are intelligent -- that's why they sent me to you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I can give you a more practical reason for your kind invitation. I know too much. I was Jacqueline's psycho-analyst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always thought it was a more intimate relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps, Natalie, this is a bargain you're offering me --I am being allowed to join -- to buy safety by betraying Jacqueline -- is that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't said anything of the sort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you would like to know where she is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. There are certain punitive measures...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can imagine. But you did say you came to me as my friend --that you were concerned for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid you have mistaken my motive, Louis. I thought you might understand and sympathize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no sympathy for either good or evil. I have only curiosity -- a professional curiosity. What unhappy people most of you are!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we?        I thought I was very gay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gay lot -В— Redi, for instance.  I don't know what her sorrow is,        but her life's an empty one. She's had to have this to cling to. Frances Fallon, with her worship of Jacqueline, has had to follow like a sheep. And Bruns, the fanatic. And you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her empty sleeve. She looks down, and her mou twists in a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a great dancer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A strange collection. You're like the false god you worship... fallen angels, all of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life has betrayed us. We've found there is no heaven on earth, so we must worship evil for evil's own sake. We're not wicked. We commit no violence, unless...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling, close to her) Unless what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pause, then smiling, sure of herself) No, you draw no secrets from me, as you drew them from Jacqueline. You are not one of us yet. You're clever, Louis, but I recognize your interest in me for what it is worth. You are only curious. You have never loved a woman who had but one arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be a charming experience. She might only protest half as much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) You're very flippant and perhaps wise, but not wise enough to see the truth, Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd walks with Mrs. Cortez to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very sincerely) What is truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cortez looks at him from the doorway in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are the first words I have ever heard you say without mockery and contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Romari, with the pigeon on the table in front of her shelling beans. As she shells them she sings an Italian s her voice ringing out merrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is in the shower. It is an old-fashioned affair with a round pipe rail above it from which a translucent curtain is hanging to keep the water from splashing. Mary head, neck, shoulders and a portion of her back can be se She is wearing a shower cap. The warm water is streaming her, making a comfortable fog of steam. Mary is humming o whistling the song that Mrs. Romari was singing downstair She lifts her hand to soap the back of her neck. A dark a threatening shadow falls athwart the curtain, and through steam and water a figure can be dimly seen standing there is a moment or two before this figure speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks toward the shower curtain and sees the grim indeterminate bulk of someone standing there. She brings hands and arms up protectively huddling all her forces together in embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her voice weak and embarrassed) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mrs. Redi, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching for the faucet) I'll be out in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That won't be necessary. I haven't much to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary turns the water off and stands listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I were you, Mary -- I'd go back to school. I'd make no further attempt to find Jacqueline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will make you unhappy to find Jacqueline. It would put her in danger --- great danger --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a little silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can almost feel your doubt about what I'm saying, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't give up looking for her, Mrs. Redi, no matter what you're hinting at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no intention whatsoever of hinting. Your sister, Mary, is a murderess. She killed Irving August -- stabbed him out of fright when he discovered where she was hiding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to help get rid of the body. You saw it on the subway. And I warn you, Mary -- go back -- you don't know what you're doing, or what dreadful things you might bring about by looking for your sister. You go back to school - - go back and forget Jacqueline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shadow of Mrs. Redi's figure leaves the curtain. The clicks shut behind her. Mary moves her hand out to part t curtain. CLOSE UP of Mary's face as seen from the other side of th shower curtain as she opens it. She is looking off at the door through which Mrs. Redi has passed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT  There is a fire burning in the fireplace. The lamps have been lit, although outdoors there is still a g cold light in the street. The room looks bright and warm. There are about a dozen people who are        standing an smoking and chatting. Before the sofa a tea service has b set on the coffee table. An alcohol stove keeps the tea w hot and a slight steam rises from the tea kettle. Among the guests can be seen certain familiar faces. Fran Fallon stands near the door talking with a young man, Mr. Durk, who can be recognized as one of the two drunks who supported the body of Irving August on the subway. The ot of the two drunks, Mr. Leo, is seated by himself in an armchair looking through a record album. In his street clothes, chatting with a very lovely, white-haired woman, Joseph, the workman at La Jeunesse. Mrs. Cortez is opening the door, as the scene opens, to a Mrs. Redi, who is dressed in exactly the same clothes she wore in the previous scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to remove her furs) I'm sorry to be late, Natalie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the furs and hanging them over the back of a chair) We haven't even begun tea yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two women cross to the sofa and sit down. On the way across the room, Mrs. Redi nods to several of the people standing about. She and Mrs. Cortez seat themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't you pour, Mrs. Redi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Redi pours out a cup of tea. Her hand trembles and s moves rather awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I'm nervous. This is very trying for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. You introduced Jacqueline to us -- but how could you tell В—-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should have known. She had no sincerity В—- no real belief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cortez pats Mrs. Redi's hand comfortingly, then turn and calls out,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cream or lemon, Frances?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances comes forward and Mr. Durk comes with her. They s beside the sofa near Mrs. Redi. Mrs. Redi pours another c of tea. Mrs. Cortez poises the cream pitcher over it. She turns to a tall dark-haired woman who is standing near th window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Rowan, do you take cream?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Rowan, without bothering to answer, strides across t room and takes the teacup from her hand. She seats hersel a small chair facing the sofa. Mrs. Redi starts to pour another cup of tea, but has a slight mishap. There is a clatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Natalie, would you mind pouring?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cortez takes the teapot in her hand and begins pouri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be nervous. There is nothing personal or vengeful in what we are about to do. We have only to make a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tall quiet woman has come up to the table. She speaks  to Mrs. Cortez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it can be such a horrible decision. I found peace here. I know that a large portion of that peace came because we are all pledged to non-violence. Now this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our founder must have known when he wrote these seemingly contradictory rules -В— the rule of non-violence and the law that whoever betrays us must die -- he must have known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can't understand it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Redi turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of us, Frances, must believe without understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she speaks, a mature, handsome, forceful man dressed i dark business suit, Mr. Bruns, comes forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went back through the history last night. I read about Johann Rozenquartz -- I read what he  wrote --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can quote it fully, Mrs. Redi. "We will avoid violence. For once undertaken, violence becomes its own master and can lead to either good or evil."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he also wrote --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I can quote that too; "Those who shall go out into the market place and let their tongues speak of us, and give knowledge of our being and our deeds, whom-so-ever doeth this shall die."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since the founding of our order there have been six betrayals and six deaths. And now there is Jacqueline В—В— she is the seventh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do anything to her-- you mustn't hurt her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she betrayed us, Frances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She never betrayed us. She was only going to a doctor -- a psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she told him, Frances. She told him about us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Frances) I know this is difficult for you. I know that you love her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't betray us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if I believed that, I would still consider her dangerous. There is the matter of Irving August's death. Without consulting me, Mrs. Redi was illВ—advised enough to have the body removed by Leo and Durk. This makes us all a party to the crime. What if there is a trial? What if Jacqueline is asked how the body was removed? Do you think, Frances, she would keep silent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long pause. He looks around the circle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a very real danger and one which forces our decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Judd -- he knows about us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will come to us of himself В—В— the man is evil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Jacqueline's sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have taken care of Mary. I've spoken to her. She's going back to school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it is decided. Leo and Durk and I will make our plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances Fallen begins to cry. Outside the streetlights go

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a small room with a skylight. There are no curtain the skylight. Behind it the night sky can be seen, and occasionally the beam of a searchlight cuts across. There a bed, an easy chair and a desk with a typewriter stand beside it. The walls of the room are almost hidden by bookcases and books, and even the mantel bears a burden o numerous volumes. Jason is seated at his desk, turned tow the typewriter. He types a line, reads it inaudibly and a the same time beats out the rhythm with his left hand on desk top. Evidently it scans, because he types another li and is about to repeat the rhythmic test on it, when ther a small knock on the door. He gets up, crosses the room a opens the door. Mary stands outside. She is dressed in th little traveling suit she wore in the first sequence and wears a hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling her into the room) Mary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shuts the door behind her, then stands to watch her as looks around the room. He smiles happily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary This is so wonderful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks at him questioningly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your being here -- your coming so unexpectedly -В— it's a wish come true --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her hand and leads her further into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to see my room. I want you to see all of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) But it's a small room, Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's grown big with time -- I've lived here with the Romari's for ten years -- the room's become part of me. I want you to see it В—В— to know me better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves at the bookcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My books --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads forward a step and bends down to touch a battere little tavern table of old maple wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My furniture --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He draws her forward still another step toward the desk a points to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My window - - through which I see the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking toward the night sky) It's beautiful -- that searchlight  - the stars --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a searchlight В—В— it's a sword blade cutting the blue cloak of a prince В—- not stars --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting; turning to face him) Jason, I'm going back to Highcliffe. I came to say good-by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason looks at her. He is silent, but his face shows her concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) I thought your coming up here to the third floor to see me В—-that it was your advent into my world. It turns out to be good-by. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go В—-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're happy here -- you like your work В—-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly senses the compulsion that had been in her wo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't that -- you said, "have to go." What could compel you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make me tell you, Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought myself your friend, Mary. Just good-bye isn't enough for a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary turns away, close to tears. Jason stands looking at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a low voice) I had begun to write again -В—that's whet I was doing when you came in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's because of Jacqueline В—В— I can't go on looking for her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You went to see Mrs. Redi... She told you something -- what was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline is a murderess she killed a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) And you believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to. It was Irving August -- everything Mrs. Redi said -В— it fits in with what I saw -В— she even knew I'd seen his body on the subway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason thinks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it is true В— there's all the more reason for you to find Jacqueline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Gregory -- he loves her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He loves you, Mary, and you'll have to tell him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's Jacqueline's husband. I can't

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She begins to cry. Jason puts his arm about her shoulders

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't tell him -- you can't even dream of loving him --        you feel guilty for not having had love enough for Jacqueline to save her from whatever it was that took her away -- I know that feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand for a moment silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you've got to tell him about Jacqueline В—- if only for the practical reason that he's a lawyer and will know what to do. I'm going to phone him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason drops his arms from her shoulder and starts for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory Ward is striding up and down the room. He seems greatly perturbed. He speaks and the CAMERA PULLS BACK to show Mary and Jason, both seated and both watching him as strides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got to be found. That's the first step. She's got to be found so that she can give herself up to the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've tried so long to find her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd could tell us -- if he would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory stops in front of Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think he knows about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's clever and he's cautious in his way. If he knew I think he'd advise her to do what I want В—- surrender herself to the police В—В— stand trial В—В— I don't think he knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could tell him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory strides on again to the end of the room, then tur to Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you find him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose so. I can pick him up somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason picks up his overcoat from the foot of the bed, and takes his hat in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason, I sometimes wonder В—В—you're so sweet to me В—- so kind and sympathetic -- I don't know how I can ever thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason looks at her for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank me? You don't need to thank me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her again and then at Gregory Ward. Evidently some idea has passed through his mind, because he turns f Mary, crosses to the table, picks up a manuscript and put into a large Manila envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile) Verse -- verse that I wrote. I need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the envelope under his arm and starts toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd walks along unconcerned and seemingly unaware that o the opposite side of the street Jason is patiently follow him. He sees his image reflected in a weighing machine mi and turns to him. The two men wave a friendly "hello." Ja ducks out of sight around a corner for a moment and then takes up Judd's trail again. Judd passes into a small apartment house. Jason follows a moment later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a selfВ—service elevator. Jason comes in and see that the elevator is in use and the sign "in use" is glow and the fourth floor button is red. He waits patiently fo the elevator to stop and presses the "down" button. When returns to the first floor he opens the outer door, then inner grill, and is about to step in when Judd suddenly appears from the other side of the elevator, reaches in a taps him on the shoulder. Jason turns around, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Don't bother going up. I can do this all night, Jason. Watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He draws Jason out of the elevator, lets the grill door s shut, passes his hand through the grillwork, pushes the button and sends the elevator up        empty. Jason grin his head. Judd takes a cigarette packet from his pocket a passes it to Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Following me to find Jacqueline?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) UhВ—huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it won't work. Love and understanding won't make a good detective out of a recalcitrant poet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Actually I want to ask two favors of you -- one as a poet В—В—        one as a detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds strange, and I'm going to be very wary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason reaches into his overcoat pocket and pulls out the Manila envelope containing the manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some time ago you spoke about my writing again. I want your help. I'd like you to bring this to your publisher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd takes the envelope and starts to open it, looking up Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is curious, Jason. Half the time you talk as if Shakespeare were not fit to tie your shoeВ—laces; now this sudden humility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should like people to read what I've written.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd looks at him and taps the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this poetry В—В— like the poetry you wrote before extols the passion and beauty of life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It goes beyond that. It praises the goodness of God and the greatness of all His works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at him quizzically)  I hope it finds as much favor as your other book -- but somehow I doubt it -- the time is out of tune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not let your publisher judge that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd starts for the door, but Jason takes a quick step af him and lays hold of his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait В—- there is that other favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me where Jacqueline is -В— we've got to find her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) You don't expect me to do that do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. When I tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scornfully interrupting) Tell me what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have good enough sense to tell us where she is -В— when you know she's a murderess. She killed a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, Gregory, Jason and Judd come around the corner and start up the lane. Gregory and Mary walk together and Jud walks with Jason behind them. Mary and Gregory go past th camera. As Judd and Jason come abreast of the CAMERA IT DOLLIES W them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, why this sudden desire to publish В— to awaken like Byron and find yourself famous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No other reason В—В— no woman В—В—not the little Miss Gibson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason walks on without answering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very sincerely) I'll do all I can to help. I'll go to my publisher tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little group of people come up to it. It is a mean li house. Mary looks up at the dark windows, glances at the garbage can full of refuse near the door, and shudders. Dr. Judd takes a key from his pocket and opens the front door. The hallway is dimly lit by a bare electric bulb. A the back can be seen an angular stairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. I'll call her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes into the house and the rest stand together on the stoop looking in through the open door. Judd crosses the and standing at the front of the stairs, calls up to Jacqueline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline, this is Judd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no answer. He waits a moment, then calls again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a frightened strained voice, that answers; a voi that seems to have come up through layers of heavy sleep, emerging only to be frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd. I'm here with your sister. Come on down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd goes forward and stands by the banister. Mary stands one side with Jason, and Gregory at the other side. They wait. Very slowly Jacqueline comes down the stairs. She has on nightgown and over it a fur coat. Her hair is loose about shoulders, her eyes are wide and apprehensive. Judd puts his hand to help her down the last few steps. Mary goes i the lighted hall. The two sisters look at each other for moment, then go into each others arms. Judd leans against banister, watching. Finally, they break from their embrac Mary is crying and Jacqueline is half-laughing, half-cryi She holds Mary off at arm's length, looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees the two men in the doorway, and starts back fearfully. Gregory steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands quite still, looking at him nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline turns back to Judd and moves a little in his direction. Judd continues to lean against the banister, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're safe. Nothing is going to hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your husband seems very sure of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again she looks from one to the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm very sure there's only one way to protect you -- to help you you've got to come with        us-- let me do all that I can as a lawyer to straighten out Irving August's death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must come with us, darling. You must let us help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary extends her arms to her sister and Jacqueline goes i them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jason) For me -В— this seems to be the end of a delightful relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd smiles and shrugs his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a bright fire in the fireplace. Jason is crouche before the fire. He has a coffee pot set up on the edges three bricks inside the fireplace, and on the hearth is a reflector baker with biscuits baking in it. A bottle of c and other oddments and endments of his culinary art are strewn about on the hearth. Jacqueline is seated before the fire in an armchair with at her feet. Mary's head is resting against Jacqueline's knee. Gregory sits on a straight chair, a little uncomfortable, and facing them from the other side of the fire. Judd lounges on the bed. Jason wraps a tea towel around his hand and reaches in th fireplace for the coffee pot. He pours out a cup of coffe and then with the same wrapped hand snatches a biscuit fr the baker, and puts it on the edge of the coffee saucer. hands it to Jacqueline. Her hand trembles as she takes it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he passes the coffee) Here, this will put some life into you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking fixedly into the fire) It's like coming back to life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline, it would be so much easier if you would tell me just what happened. I'd know what to do for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline shakes her head,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Jacqueline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know about the Palladists -- you know who they are -- what they are. I was one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pauses, and Judd in moving from his place on the bed, speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline was always a sensationalist, trying to seize onto something -- anything -- in order to find happiness. Through Mrs. Redi she stumbled onto the Palladist movement В—- it appealed to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shuddering) I wasn't happy with them -- wanted to break away В—В— was miserable. I went to Louis for help. They felt that I had betrayed them. They wanted me to die -- to kill myself. They kept me locked up at La Jeunesse. I was there such a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can Imagine the effect of such imprisonment on Jacqueline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was terrified. The darkness in the corners of the room --the little noises. Then one night the door opened -- a man came in В—В— tipВ—toeing in. I had a scissors in my hand -- I struck at him, I ran away. He was lying in the hall with the blood around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shudders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (comforting her) Don't. We know what happened. Don't go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any court in the land would understand. We'll wait a few days -- let you rest -- then we'll go to the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will all be over in such a little while, Jacqueline, and everything will be all right again. Drink your coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline raises the cup to her lips and sips. Jason bus himself at the fire again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I might close up the apartment -- maybe get a place in Connecticut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd love that, Jackie. Remember that last summer with Mother in the Berkshires? You used to help the gardener.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. You could become a country wife -- fool around with petunias and pullets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will be fun meeting Gregory every night at the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right Jacqueline, I thought you'd like it. We could just stay on at the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never liked the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it. I've always loved the story -- man, knowing that he couldn't have the woman he loved and wooing her for his friend. We're friends, aren't we, Gregory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory turns away self-consciously. Jacqueline continues look into the fire without answering. Judd looks over at Jason. He sees what plan lies in the poet's mind. Getting his feet, he crosses to Jacqueline and Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a hard evening for both of you. Perhaps you'd better take Jacqueline to your room, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the cup from Jacqueline's hand and puts it on t mantel. Jacqueline rises; Mary puts her arm around her wa and they start for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Jacqueline -- good night, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline does not answer. The two girls pass out of the door, and Mary closes the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Jason) I'm afraid this is no time to play Cyrano, my friend. What was in your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to get things clear for Jacqueline. Let her know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let her know what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you love Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll have to know some time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves off toward the door. Judd lingers for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose, Jason, that you'll speak for your friend -- (indicating Gregory) -- and your poetry will speak for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house door opens, and Mary comes out onto the stoop dressed for the street. Jacqueline is with her, but remai in the doorway. Jacqueline is dressed in a negligee. Mary steps into the bright morning sunlight. Somewhere do the street a hurdy-gurdy is playing, and along the sidewa pass children on their way to school, their faces fresh scrubbed, books under their arms. Mary kisses Jacqueline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-bye, darling. I'll only be gone until three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you get lonely, go down and see Mrs. Romari. I told her you were staying with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't get lonely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary runs down the stairs. At the foot of the stairs she turns to smile at Jacqueline. Jacqueline smiles back sadl Mary turns, walks off a few steps, then turns back again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary waves and goes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA IS FIXED at the spot in the apartment where th Palladists had grouped themselves during the meeting.  There is no one present, but the chairs are still in the disorderly pattern to which they had been pulled during t meeting. There is the sound of a door buzzer, and the light tread feet as someone crosses the room at the other end and ans the door. The door can be heard opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis Judd! I'm amazed to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Natalie. I wouldn't have disturbed you if it weren't for a matter of grave concern to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs  Cortez and Judd come into the scene  She is in negli He is dressed in street clothes with his overcoat over hi arm and hat in band. He stops and looks moodily at the od spaced collection of chairs. Mrs. Cortez seats herself on arm of the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) I thought nothing concerned you, Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands silently staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it about Jacqueline?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with the air of one who dismisses a trivial matter) No. She's no longer under my care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cortez looks at him in astonishment. He is too absor to notice this start on her part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how to begin this, Natalie. Perhaps it's best to just plunge in. I want to join you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) We always knew you'd come to us, Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm not coming to you out of deep conviction, I'm coming to you out of loss. I no longer can believe in the power and the rightness of things that are called good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never thought you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've talked nonsense. I've scoffed and hooted -- but somewhere very deep down in me, I always felt that good held the balance of power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're even sentimental about it. What made you change your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd holds up a large Manila envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These. They're Jason's poems, and they've been rejected by m publisher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cortez laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is incredible I It must be some sort of a joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very, very serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quite seriously) But you have never liked Jason. You always laughed at him - -quarreled with him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I love and admire him more than any man I ever knew. I read these poems. He's lost his talent and his was a really great gift. What I have to do today -- to bring him this rejected manuscript -В—will be the most disheartening thing I have ever done and the most disillusioning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd starts for the door. Mrs. Cortez goes with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling, still quite social) This is the most amusing thing I have ever heard and with a bit of gossip to season it В—В— your failure with Jacqueline. Has she returned to her husband?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carelessly) No, she's with her sister,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd leaves. Mrs. Cortez watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is seated on a straight-back chair, and the children around her in a circle, some seated on the floor, some standing in the second row. They are singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oranges and lemons Say the bells of St. Clemens You owe me five farthings Say the bells of St. Martin When will you pay me Say the bells of St. Bailey That I don't know Says the great bell of Bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children laugh delightedly and are so busy with their mirth that they forget to sing the next verse. Mary, smil at their glee, goes on alone. The telephone at her desk rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here comes a candle To light you to bed Here comes a chopper To chop off your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, still singing, crosses the room and mimics the chop gesture of the last phrase as she reaches for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yes, this is Mary...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she couldn't have gone out. No. Are you sure it wasn't Jason she went with, or Mr. Ward? Two men? No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she speaks, it can be seen she is greatly excited. She listens a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get home as soon as I can, Mr. Romari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts down the telephone and crosses over to where the children are grouped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children, I want you to be very good and very quiet while I see Mrs. Wheeler a moment. She's going to take over this class for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I have something very important to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right back with Mrs. Wheeler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary goes out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline is seated in a high-backed chair. The light from the window shines directly into her face. Before her a little tabouret on which stands a single glass containi some colorless liquid. Her face is very white. Around her, some seated, and some standing, are the Palladists. Bruns stands near her chair, looking down at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The acceptance of a secret is an obligation and in this case my dear, the obligation carried with it the necessity of dying if one betrayed that secret. You understand that don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, you also understand that you must die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruns shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline, you have spoken so often of ending it all, I can't understand why this should be so difficult for you. You have only to drink a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Jacqueline. You were always talking suicide - - of ending your life when you wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. You want to now. You should want to. It's your obligation, your duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have only to stretch out your hand, take up the glass and drink a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly spacing her words; evenly but not hysterically) No. No. No.

dialogues.speaker: TNT. JASON'S APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Jason stares at the window looking at the darkening sky. is still wearing his overcoat and sitting on the bed, sta at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both Harrison and Conroy read your stuff. They felt as I did --old fashioned sentiment -- weak --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men are silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take this all very well, Jason. I thought you'd be much more bitter, but tell me -В— why is it you were suddenly moved to publish? You wanted to bring fame to lay at her feet. And now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't suppose you'll ever tell her, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is very young -- I have an old habit of failure. It would be a bad habit to bring to a marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A book of successful verse might have changed that, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a strange kind of courage, Jason. Perhaps you have courage enough to hear what I have been keeping from you all these years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That girl you loved -В— that other patient of mine -В— she didn't disappear. She's in an asylum -В—a horrible, raving thing. I never wanted you to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason looks at him for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -В—В—and all the while you've been my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is almost dark. The lamps have not yet been ligh Only Jacqueline's white and tortured features catch the l cold light from the window. The rest of the Palladists ar darkness.
