At the piano someone sits playing. It is Mrs. Cortez. She plays with only one hand, with a deadly monot and a curious unevenness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who is weak and tired) May I have some water? I'm thirsty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't get any water and you won't get any rest. You may as well drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline makes no answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing to live for. Jacqueline. Remember В—В— you gave me La Jeunesse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It may not mean anything to you, Jacqueline but what about your youth, your beauty? It's all going, and you were proud. Prouder than I ever was of my dancing Jacqueline. I remember when this happened -В— (touches her arm) This robbed me of my dancing  В—robbed me of my skill. I remember how lost I was until I found peace. You have lost that peace, Jacqueline. You have betrayed evil. There's nothing left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's my husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Little you care about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline shudders. Mrs. Redi bends over the little tabo and pushes the glass of poison closer to Jacqueline. Jacqueline shrinks away, screaming hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cortez turns back to play the piano and drown her ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason and Judd come out of the house and start down tho stairs  When they are midway down the stairs the restaura door opens and Mary comes out and goes across the little space toward the street steps. Judd and Jason arc talking they go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you like, I'll go with you to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary hears his voice and looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men turn toward the stair rail and bend over it toward Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't find Gregory. I've been trying to find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong, Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline. Mr. Romari phoned me. She went out this afternoon with two men he'd never seen before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They may have been friends of hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, She wouldn't have gone with anyone unless she were compelled. All these months of hiding have made her frightened of the streets and people. I wonder --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason comes down to the street level and takes Mary's han comfortingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They may have found her. (he thinks a minute) Mrs. Cortez -В— this morning I told her Jacqueline was no longer under my care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would they hurt her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better go to your room, Mary and wait for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes Mary's arm and turns her toward the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only two lamps are lit, one a small table lamp and the ot a tall standing lamp which throws a pool of light around Jacqueline. The beams of the other lamp gleam on the eyes the dark faces around her. There is a deep silence in the apartment. After a moment, Bruns' voice, grown hoarse, ca heard speaking from the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Jacqueline Go ahead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The words drop into the silence like stones in a pool of still water, and the silence closes over them, Jacqueline moves her position a little bit. Her movements are slow a she moves without disturbing the stillness of the room. M Cortez' light voice comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is late -В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again there is silence, end again Jacqueline shifts her position just a little bit. Suddenly the stillness of the scene, the almost tableau arrangement of the character, i shattered. Frances Fallon jumps hysterically to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hysterically; completely unnerved) Drink Jacqueline! Drink! You've got to drink. There's nothing else. Drink! Drink! Drink! I can't stand this. You've got to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very slowly Jacqueline's hand goes forward and seizes the stem of the glass. Slowly she brings it up to her lips. Frances, suddenly, knocks the glass from her hand. It goe crashing to the floor. Frances, sobbing, falls at Jacqueline's feet, embracing her knees and weeping bitter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobbing) No, no. I couldn't see you die. You were so good to me -В— so good to me. I was never happier than when I worked for you В—В— never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs  Cortez reaches back of her and snaps on the wall lig The whole room is filled with a hard, white light. Jacque has not moved. Frances continues to sob at her knee. The get up stiffly and move awkwardly about. Bruns and Leo whisper together. Bruns comes over to Jacqueline end stan before her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can go. The decision was against violence. There may be another decision В—В— today - В—tomorrow В—В— and we will find you, but now you can go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline makes no move to rise, but continues to sit wi dead, set face, looking ahead of her, with Frances still weeping at her knee. Bruns takes her arm roughly and pull her to her feet. In the background Leo can be seen going of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you you could go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She seems to be aware of what he has said for the first t She starts for the door, almost stumbling as she walks. Jacqueline goes through the front door without looking ba and without closing the door behind her. Mrs. Cortez walk forward and shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline comes out of Mrs. Cortez' apartment and stands a moment in a broad patch of light thrown by the open doo Behind her this door closes and she is suddenly in darkne She looks apprehensively into the shadows and then quite hesitantly begins to walk to the right. At the end of the street the brighter lights of Fifth Avenue can be seen. Washington News, itself, is full of dark shadows. She is exhausted and unnerved. She walks slowly. She pass one place where the outВ—jutting of the building casts a deeper shadow on the sidewalk. A garbage can is set behin the outВ—jutting, this and the bough of an old ailanthus combine to cast a man-like shadow beside the shadow of th building. Jacqueline pauses, peers intently into the shad then summons up courage enough to pass. She walks quickly past the out-jutting building. Somewhat relieved, she wal little bit more confidently. Suddenly, there is a clatter bang of metal behind her. She gasps, startled, and whirls around A white dog with a long bony tail slinks away from a garb can. The lid of this can is still oscillating from its fa and roll. Jacqueline draws her coat more closely about her and goes Ahead of her, thrown by the thin light from a transom abo door, is the enormously long shadow of a man across the sidewalk and across the street. She hesitates then starts cross the street diagonally, looking back all the while a the doorway. From the center of the street it can be seen that a man stands there. With him stands a woman, her fig somewhat lost in the doorway. They are saying good night. the opposite side of the street, Jacqueline hurries towar the Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With evident relief, Jacqueline comes out of the darkness Washington News to the more brightly lighted avenue. Traf is passing and people are all about her. She starts off u the avenue with confidence. Then some premonition makes h turn. Only a few paces behind her is Leo, and there is a on his lean, satyr-like face. She hurries her step. Behind her Leo quickens his pace. I She peers into the faces of passers-by, seeking some unpreoccupied person who might be sympathetic and helpful People pass her, intent on their own business and without concern. She begins to run. Leo merely lengthens his stri It is easy for him to keep up with her. A few people turn their heads to watch her run, but Leo's long strides attr no attention. Suddenly, in desperation, she dashes across street. A cab narrowly misses hitting her and a bus, comi from the other direction, has to stop with an appalling scream and roar of brakes. Jacqueline, shaken, out of breath and trembling, reaches other corner of the- street. She pauses for a moment to t a deep breath. She looks back of' her. There is no sign o Leo. Again she starts on and from the shadow of a light standard a deeper shadow detaches itself and steps out be her. It is Leo and he is grinning. She sees him and begin run down the cross street. She runs wildly. Leo, at first lengthens his stride, and then suddenly breaks into a lop a lope that will bring him up to her within an instant. She ducks into an alley and is lost in the darkness. She hides in a corner amid some debris, crouching back out of light. Leo plunges ahead in pursuit. Jacqueline stands a moment as the sound of his footsteps diminish, then turns back and begins running down the street. Ahead of her, a slim figure, not unlike Leo's, is walking up the street toward her. She dodges into the next alley. This is an alley behind a theatre. It is cluttered with all sorts of strange impedimenta; flats, crates, etc. There is an overhead lam burning in the center of the alley, but the periphery of light beneath it, does not extend to the walls of the all The area immediately adjacent to these walls is heavy wit darkness and strange shadows. Jacqueline stands in the mi of the pool of light and listens. It seems to her that sh can hear in the darkness the soft tap-tap of someone walk on his toes. She shrinks back from the bright light into darkness and begins to grope her way along the wall, She going from left to right. A sound at her right attracts h attention and she looks off, but continues to grope her w along the wall to the left. Her hand passes from the roughness of the wall to the smoothness of cloth and a sp second later, Leo, whom she has touched, grins as he seiz her wrist. She screams and then silently struggles to fre herself. Still smiling he holds her firmly with his right band. With his left hand he draws something from his pock He presses a button on this and a four-and a-half inch kn blade flashes out. Jacqueline stands stock still with fri Leo's hand goes back for the blow. At the opposite side of the alley a door is suddenly thro wide open and a great patch of light is thrown on Jacquel and Leo. He puts the knife behind his back. Out of the door come half a dozen people in costumes. The are members of a ballet company performing in the theatre Also there emerges the sound of loud and merry music. The actors are in a gay mood laughing and shouting. One o them breaks into a half dance step. It is infectious and rest join in, making a sort of Carmagnole that sweeps dow the alley. Jacqueline breaks from Leo's hand-hold on her wrist and runs in among them. One of the dancers is an enormous man dressed in Roman ha armor to represent the god Gambrinus, with gilded hop blo as a garland about his shoulders and wearing a papier mac mask, surmounted by crown of similarly gilded hop leaves wheat. The face of the mask is a grinning, jolly, rubicun visage.  It is next to this enormous man that Jacqueline finds herself. In sportive mood the giant dancer sweeps h up with one arm, forcing her to dance his grotesque steps

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. Please. Let me down. There's a man following me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a booming voice) I shouldn't wonder, Babe. I shouldn't wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious В—В— help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll help you to a beer and a sandwich. Come along, babe, come along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole party of dancers with Jacqueline among them, go roaring out of the alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the street corner is a beer saloon. The dancers, some them still skipping and dancing, come around and go into brilliantly lit saloon. The dancer with Jacqueline tries pull her into the saloon. She fights away from him. Laugh and slapping his thigh in mirth, he leaves her and passes into the saloon. She is left alone in the street. She mak halfВ—hearted movement to adjust her disarranged clothing Slowly, with great weariness, she begins to walk away fro the saloon, going further and further into the darkness. looks around. The darkness frightens her. She looks back. There is the warm glow of light from the saloon windows. starts to go back. From the lighted end of the street a m crosses to the same side of the street as Jacqueline. His silhouette somewhat resembles the silhouette of Leo. She turns, runs and is lost in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Palladists, with the exception of Leo, are all here a all seated. Judd, still wearing his overcoat, is seated i small chair facing them and beside him stands Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that you've hounded and worried her half to death, you don't oven know where she is. At least tell me, has she been here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was here for a little while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. She left here an hour or so ago. She may even be home now. Why don't you try it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judd gets up and they start for the door. Half-way to the door, Jason stops and turns around. Judd also turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around the room and peering at each person in turn) The devil worshipers -- the lovers off evil. It's a joke-В—a pathetic little joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've not asked your opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I propose to give it to you anyway. You're a poor, wretched group of people who have taken the wrong turning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong? Who knows what is right or wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can prove you wrong so simply Listen: (he bows his head and recites very quietly) Our father who art in heaven Hallowed be thy name Thy kingdom come, thy will be done On earth as it is in heaven. Give us this day, our daily bread Forgive us our trespasses as we Forgive those who trespass against us. Lead us not into temptation But deliver us from evil For thine is the kingdom, the power And the glory forever. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he prays, the CAMERA MOVES FROM one off the Palladists another. Tears form in Frances Fallon's eyes. Mrs. Redi t her head. Even Bruns, the ardent and fanatical believer, chokes back a sob. Both men turn and go. The CAMERA HOLDS ON the Palladist group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline, still running, comes into the scene and goes the steps. She opens the front door and lets herself in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gas light has been turned down so that there is only tiny flame to illuminate the hall. The draft in the hallw stirs this little flame and the shadows move with it. Jacqueline comes up the stairs. Now that she can be seen closely, it can be seen also that she is exhausted, her e wild, her hair in disorder. She almost staggers as she reaches the landing and goes slowly supporting herself on banisters, toward Mary's door. Her way brings her past Ro #7, the room with the noose. For a moment she stands weak staring at the door, then goes on. She has reached Mary's room, has crossed the narrow hallway and her hand is almo on the knob when Mimi's door opens and Mimi, white nightВ—gowned, comes out into the eerie gas light. Jacque looks at her face which is distorted and horrible in the moving shadows and flickering light. She stifles a scream The other girl is also frightened. The two stand staring each other for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Mimi -- I'm dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It's been quiet, oh ever so quiet. I hardly move, yet it keeps coming all the time -В—closer and closer. I rest and rest and yet I am dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you don't want to die. I've always wanted to die -- always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacqueline shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired of being afraid -В— of waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why wait?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with sudden determination) I'm not going to wait. I'm going out -- laugh, dance --do all the things I used to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very softly end almost with envy) You will die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Mimi has already turned back into her room. Jacquelin stands watching until the light snaps on in Mimi's room a then the door closing, plunges the hall into weird half l again. In this semi-darkness, she turns away from Mary's and walks down the hall toward room #7. She opens the doo and goes in. For a brief moment the light from the hall c the shadow of a noose against the further wall of the roo and then the door closes behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is lit by a single little lamp on the dressing t В— Mary herself stands near the window, looking out. Greg is talking over the telephone. From downstairs we hear Mr Romari singing. The song comes faintly to this upper stor She is singing an Italian song. The words are Dante's:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Death, why hast thou made life so hard to bear, Taking my lady hence? East thou no whit or shame? The youngest flowers and the most fair Thou hast pluck'd. away and the world wanteth it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory puts down the telephone and crosses to the window

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was Dr. Judd. He was phoning to say that, Jacqueline is on her way here -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory В—В— (pauses then goes on) you'd better take Jacqueline with you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what I should have done yesterday. I'll take her away somewhere where she can rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary turns back toward the window. Gregory stands watchin her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns toward him. He puts his hands on her shoulders turns her back to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Stay that way. I want to talk to you. I love you -В— you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a choked voice ) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps, later, when things are settled, when Jacqueline's well again -- maybe we can arrange things differently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary turns and faces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never loved any one before, Gregory, and I do love you -В— you must know it -- but Jacqueline's my sister В—В— whom I had lost and have found again.... (breaks off,) (shaking her) (head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know В—В— I shouldn't have told youВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm glad....at least I've heard you say it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary shakes her head, turns back toward the window. They stand together for a moment. From below comes the sound o Mrs. Romari's singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA IS LEVELED on the empty hall. From downstairs can be heard the sound of Mrs. Romari singing. Then Mimi' door opens and Mimi sweeps out, dressed in a black dress, gleaming with sequins, her hair piled high, her walk prou and steady. She comes down the hall toward the camera. Ju as she reaches the door of #7, there is the sound of an overВ—turned chair falling. She pauses and looks toward t door. There is the creaking sound of the rope. She listen for an instant, and failing to comprehend, sweeps on past camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a bright day and the sunlit street can be seen thro the windows. Children are hurrying by on their way to sch At a table near the window Mary sits with Gregory. She ha been crying and has her sodden handkerchief in her hand. Gregory has a pre-occupied air and is tracing figures on table cloth with his fork. Jason comes in bearing a small tray with three tiny cups coffee on it. He puts a cup in front of each of them and keeps one for himself. He sips his coffee. Neither Mary nor Gregory touch theirs Jason pushes Mary's toward her to attract her attention, She picks it up and brings it to her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate people who try to peddle comfort. But,Mary, you shouldn't mourn for Jacqueline. Life for her was full of the agony of a disordered mind. It's better this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep telling myself that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, tell yourself, Mary, that this is a world that doesn't pass with the passing of any one of us. All three of us are going to start afresh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up and across at Jason with a meaningful glance Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and I have new hopes В—В— and new plans can come from them В—В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason looks at him across Mary and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not I В—- I am alive, yet every hope I had is dead, (turns to Mary) Death can be good. Death can be happy.. If I were really dying I could speak like Cyrano -В— "My courage like a white plume" В— and all the other lovely words with which he greeted death. Then perhaps you might understand,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching over to touch  (his band) I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Good. We all understand each other. You, Gregory and I. We all know. There is sunlight in the streets and work to do. Both of you -В— you're off to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and takes Mary's arm, helping her to rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off with you. You can't sit here in this cellar with the sun shining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hustles her toward the door and Gregory follows. Mary Gregory ascend the steps to the street level. Jason steps back a pace or two so that he is backgrounded the mural of Dante. He stands there, and the smile leaves face. His whole body reflects his hopelessness and despai It is at this moment that Mrs. Romari comes hustling in f the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! Good! They have all gone! Now you and I can laugh and joke again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to her, forcing a smile.
